novel_text:
The old cypress knees of St. Jude’s-in-the-Swamp had heard it all. They’d soaked in the somber dirges of a hundred funerals and the reedy triumph of a thousand Easter hymns. But they had never heard anything quite like the sound Reverend Amelia Cartwright was making on this particular Tuesday afternoon. It started as a low, mournful hum, a note that seemed to rise from the very peat and loam of the Gainesville earth, then it caught, climbed, and unfurled into a ribbon of pure, gut-punching soul. It wasn't a hymn, not unless Aretha Franklin had secretly been rewriting the hymnal. It was a lament, a plea, and a defiant roar all at once, bouncing off the vaulted ceiling and making the dust motes dance in the slanted columns of afternoon light.

Amelia, her black clerical shirt sticking to her back in the humid air, held the final note until her lungs burned, her eyes shut tight. In that moment, she wasn't the Reverend Cartwright, the one who counseled grieving widows and argued about the font for the church newsletter. She was just Amy, a woman with a voice too big for her body, a sound forged in a crucible of gospel choirs and her daddy’s scratchy blues records. The silence that followed was heavier, more profound, than the note itself. It was a silence filled with the ghost of the song. She opened her eyes, a giddy smile playing on her lips. The empty pews were her most honest audience. They never judged.

The spell was broken by the shrill, profane shriek of the telephone from her office, a sound as jarring in the sanctuary's peace as a firecracker in a library. Amelia sighed, the last of the melody evaporating from the air. Reality, in the form of church business, always called. She padded across the cool flagstones, her sensible shoes making soft, apologetic sounds. "St. Jude's, Reverend Cartwright speaking," she said, her voice dropping back into its usual gentle, pastoral cadence.

"Amy! It's Chad! From the show!" The voice on the other end was a thousand miles away from Gainesville, all L.A. sunshine, caffeine, and naked ambition. Chad, the junior producer for ‘America’s Next Voice,’ a man who spoke in exclamation points.

Amelia’s heart did a frantic little tap-dance against her ribs. "Chad. Hello. Any news?" She tried to keep her voice even, to sound like a woman who had more important things to think about than a televised singing competition. It was a terrible piece of acting.

"News? Honey, I have THE news! You're in! The final! The network loved the semi-final tape. The whole 'singing vicar' angle is gold, pure gold! They're flying you out Sunday. First-class. We’re putting you up at the Mondrian. Is that insane or is that insane?!"

Amelia sank into her creaky office chair, the receiver suddenly slippery in her palm. The Mondrian. First-class. The Final. The words were alien, shimmering things, landing in her small, cluttered office with its smell of old paper and lemon polish. She looked at the wall, at the framed photo of her ordination, the bishop looking stern, herself looking young and terrified. What would he think of the Mondrian? "I… I don't know what to say, Chad."

"Say you'll be there! Say you're ready to blow the roof off the place! We've got Marco the Crooner, that little pop-punk kid Skyler, and you. The holy trinity of vocal warfare! It's gonna be epic, Amy. Epic!"

Holy trinity. Amelia almost choked on a laugh. Oh, if only he knew. "I'll be there, Chad," she managed, a wave of giddiness making her feel lightheaded. "I'll be there."

When she hung up, the silence of the office rushed back in, but it was a different kind of silence now. It was electric. She stood up, walked back into the sanctuary, and stood in the very spot where she’d been singing. The light was fading, turning the stained-glass depiction of St. Jude, patron saint of lost causes, into a jewel-toned mosaic. A lost cause. That’s what her father had called her desire to be a singer. 'You have the voice of an angel, Amy-girl,' he'd said, his own voice rough with whiskey and regret, 'but this world chews up angels and spits 'em out.' And so she’d chosen a different flock, a different kind of service. Yet, here it was. The lost cause, found. She threw her head back and let out a laugh that was pure, unadulterated joy, a sound that sent the pigeons roosting in the belfry scattering into the purple dusk. The Reverend Amelia Cartwright was going to Hollywood.

Her church secretary, Beatrice, a woman whose sharp angles and sharper tongue concealed a heart of surprising softness, was less effusive. When Amelia told her the news the next morning over lukewarm coffee and a plate of day-old muffins, Beatrice simply raised a perfectly sculpted eyebrow. "Los Angeles," she said, as if tasting a word she found foul. "They're not Episcopalian out there, you know. They worship gluten-free toast and their own reflections."

"Bea, be nice. This is a huge opportunity," Amelia said, still buzzing with an energy that felt foreign and wonderful.

"It's an opportunity to be humiliated on national television by a man named 'Marco the Crooner,' who I'm sure is as oily as a mechanic's rag," Beatrice retorted, tapping a perfectly manicured nail on the stack of mail. "And what about the parish? Who's going to officiate the bake sale on Saturday? Who's going to listen to Mrs. Higgins's weekly complaint about the length of the new hymn?"

"You are," Amelia said with a grin. "And you'll be brilliant. It’s just for a week or so. Think of it as a mission trip. I'm going into the wilderness to spread the good word."

"The good word of Leiber and Stoller, perhaps," Beatrice sniffed, but a tiny smile betrayed her. "Alright. Go on. Go be a star. But if you come back with a vocal fry and a chihuahua in your purse, I'm resigning." She paused, her expression softening for a fraction of a second. "Just… be careful, Amy. That world isn't like this one. It’s all teeth."

The warning echoed in Amelia’s mind a few days later as she stood in her bedroom, a black clerical robe laid out on the bed next to a shimmering, peacock-blue dress she’d bought on a whim. The two garments looked like emissaries from warring nations. One represented duty, solemnity, peace. The other, hope, audacity, and a terrifying, thrilling vanity. She picked up her collar, the stiff white plastic cool against her fingers. She had worn it for so long it felt like a part of her skin. Could she be Amy the singer without betraying Amelia the Reverend? The congregation’s reaction had been a mixed bag of Southern charm and suspicion. Most were thrilled, planning viewing parties and making signs. But she’d overheard old Mr. Abernathy muttering to his wife about "worldly temptations" and "making a spectacle of the cloth."

She was making a spectacle, wasn't she? A spectacle of joy. A spectacle of a gift she had tried to keep tucked away, using it only for the glory of God in the most literal sense. But the gift didn't want to be tucked away. It wanted the stage lights. It wanted to reach people who would never set foot in St. Jude’s-in-the-Swamp. She folded the robe carefully and placed it in her suitcase. Then, she picked up the blue dress. The sequins felt like armor. She held it up to herself in the mirror, and for a moment, she saw a stranger looking back. A woman on the precipice of a different life, her eyes wide with a holy and profane terror. The plane ticket was on her dresser. Los Angeles was waiting. St. Jude, patron of lost causes, was either smiling down on her or shaking his head in dismay. Amelia couldn't decide which. And for the first time in a long time, she found she didn't much care. She was flying.The small Gainesville airport felt like an extension of her own parish. A handful of congregants had turned up for a semi-official send-off, armed with Tupperware containers of pimento cheese sandwiches and a handmade banner that read "SING FOR THE LORD AND GAINESVILLE, AMELIA!" Mrs. Higgins pressed a Ziploc bag of ginger snaps into her hand, "For your nerves, dear," while Beatrice stood by, arms crossed, looking as if she were supervising a particularly risky hostage exchange. She adjusted Amelia’s collar, which Amelia had decided to wear as a sort of shield. “Remember,” Beatrice whispered, her voice a low conspiracy, “Hydrate. Don’t sign anything without reading it thrice. And for heaven’s sake, don’t let them talk you into a spray tan.” The advice was so practical, so Beatrice, that Amelia hugged her fiercely, smelling her familiar scent of Earl Grey tea and righteous indignation. It was the smell of home.

First class was less a section of a plane and more a different dimension. The seat was a plush, cream-colored pod that looked more comfortable than her couch back home. A flight attendant with a smile as bright and flawless as a strip of porcelain veneers offered her champagne before they’d even left the ground. Amelia, flustered, asked for a ginger ale instead. She watched her small town shrink below her, the familiar grid of streets and the green sprawl of Paynes Prairie Preserve giving way to a patchwork of clouds. She pulled out her well-worn Book of Common Prayer, its pages soft as cloth, intending to read the evening service. But her eyes kept straying to the window, to the impossibly blue sky stretching out towards a future she couldn't begin to imagine. The ancient words of the psalter felt distant, their rhythm competing with the thrum of the jet engines and the frantic, syncopated beat of her own heart. She wasn't just flying west; she felt like she was accelerating away from a fixed point, a known self, at a thousand miles an hour.

The sensory assault began the moment she stepped out of the hermetically sealed environment of LAX. The air didn't wrap around you with a damp embrace like it did in Florida; it was a dry, gasoline-tinged heat that felt like standing too close to a furnace. The light was different, too—a relentless, white glare that bleached the color from the sky and seemed to demand sunglasses as a matter of self-preservation. A young woman who looked no older than twenty, holding a tablet with ‘AMY CARTWRIGHT’ glowing on it in futuristic script, intercepted her. "Amy! Hi! I'm Paisley, your talent liaison! Welcome to L.A.! Traffic was a beast, but you are going to LOVE the hotel. We are all, like, *so* psyched to have you." Paisley spoke in a breathless rush, as if she were perpetually two minutes late for the most important event of her life. She led Amelia to a black SUV so polished it reflected the airport's chaotic ballet of arrivals and departures with unnerving clarity.

The drive to West Hollywood was a dizzying montage of the foreign and the familiar. Palm trees lined the freeways, but they were taller, skinnier, and sadder-looking than the ones back home. Billboards the size of houses loomed over them, advertising TV shows and impossibly beautiful people selling impossibly expensive watches. Paisley kept up a constant, chirpy monologue about vocal coaches, wardrobe fittings, and press junkets, the words washing over Amelia like a foreign language she only half-understood. She stared out the window at the endless stream of cars, the sun-drenched storefronts with names like "Go Get Em Tiger" and "Gracias Madre," and felt a profound, unnerving sense of dislocation. This wasn't the wilderness Beatrice had spoken of; it was a different planet, one that operated on its own strange physics and followed its own inscrutable commandments.

The Mondrian hotel rose up from the Sunset Strip like a giant, minimalist white cube, devoid of the ornamentation and history Amelia found comforting. The lobby was a stage set for a play she hadn't been given the script for. Impossibly long-legged women in tiny dresses navigated the space on stiletto heels, while men with carefully curated stubble and expensive-looking t-shirts conducted hushed, important-sounding conversations on their phones. The air smelled of white lilies and money. As Paisley checked her in, Amelia stood by her worn suitcase, feeling conspicuous in her simple black slacks and clerical shirt. She felt like a crow that had accidentally flown into a flock of exotic birds. When the receptionist handed her a key card, a sleek piece of plastic with no discernible teeth, she clutched it like a talisman. This, she thought, was the key to the kingdom. She just wasn't sure if she wanted to go inside.Her room was a study in white. The walls, the enormous bed with its mountain of pillows, the sleek, low-slung furniture—it was all a pristine, almost clinical white, punctuated only by a single, vibrant blue art piece on the wall that looked like a controlled explosion of paint. A floor-to-ceiling window made up the entire far wall, offering a breathtaking, terrifying vista of Los Angeles spread out below like a carpet of glittering jewels. The sounds of the city, a distant chorus of sirens and traffic, were completely sealed out, creating a silent, sterile bubble high above the chaos of the Sunset Strip. Amelia placed her scuffed suitcase on a luggage rack that looked like a museum sculpture and felt an acute sense of being an imposter, a drab sparrow in a minimalist cage built for birds of paradise.

Unpacking felt like an act of quiet rebellion, of claiming a tiny corner of this alien territory as her own. She placed her Book of Common Prayer on the glass nightstand, its worn leather cover a stark contrast to the glossy surface. Next to it, she set a small, silver-framed photo of her parents, smiling on a fishing boat in the Cedar Key flats. She hung her simple dresses in the cavernous, illuminated closet, where they looked meager and plain. When she pulled out the black clerical robe and the peacock-blue dress, the dilemma she'd faced in her bedroom returned with a new, sharper urgency. Here, in this room with a view of the Hollywood Hills, the two garments seemed less like warring emissaries and more like costumes for two entirely different plays. One was a life of service she knew and understood; the other was a glittering improvisation into the unknown.

Paisley called an hour later, her voice crackling with manufactured urgency. "Amy! Hope you're settling in! We're doing a super low-key welcome dinner for you, Marco, and Skyler up at the Skybar. In thirty! It’s just to, you know, vibe and connect before the madness begins. See you there!" Before Amelia could ask what one wore to "vibe and connect," the line went dead. She looked from her collar to the sequined dress. The choice felt too binary, too absolute. In the end, she compromised, choosing a simple black dress that could have been at home at a church potluck, but she left the collar in its box. It felt both too aggressive and too vulnerable for a rooftop bar. She felt stripped of her armor, armed only with Mrs. Higgins's ginger snaps, which she'd put in her purse for courage.

The Skybar was an open-air pavilion surrounding a pool that glowed with an ethereal blue light. The air was thick with perfume and the low throb of electronic music. Everywhere she looked, beautiful people lounged on white couches, holding drinks and laughing with a practiced, camera-ready ease. Chad spotted her immediately and bounded over, a human exclamation point in a linen blazer. "Amy! There she is! Our soulful songbird! Come, meet the competition." He steered her toward a cabana where two figures were silhouetted against the glittering city lights. "Marco, Skyler, this is Amelia!"

Marco the Crooner unfolded himself from the couch with the fluid grace of a panther. He was even more handsome than his publicity photos suggested, with dark, soulful eyes, a chin that could cut glass, and a smile that seemed to have its own dedicated lighting. He was, as Beatrice had predicted, breathtakingly smooth. He took Amelia’s hand, his grip warm and firm. "Reverend," he said, his voice a low, velvety murmur. "An honor. I saw your semi-final performance. That last note gave me chills. You're the real deal." He made it sound like a compliment, but it felt like a sizing-up, a professional assessment from a seasoned opponent.

The other finalist, Skyler, didn't get up. They remained slouched in the corner of the couch, a riot of pink hair, black eyeliner, and ripped denim, their face illuminated by the glow of their phone. They looked up, offered a distracted, "Hey," and immediately looked back down at their screen. They couldn’t have been older than twenty, radiating a carefully constructed aura of disinterest that was, in its own way, as much a performance as Marco's effortless charm. Amelia suddenly felt a hundred years old. Chad clapped his hands together. "The holy trinity! The Soul, the Swoon, and the Scream! This is ratings gold, people! Gold!" The phrase, which had seemed absurdly funny in her quiet office, felt crass and reductive here, stripping them of their humanity and turning them into marketable archetypes. She was no longer Amelia Cartwright; she was 'The Soul.'

Amelia took a seat on the edge of the couch, clutching her purse on her lap. Marco, ever the gentleman, flagged down a waiter and ordered a bottle of champagne, "To celebrate the three of us." When the waiter came to her, Amelia, feeling the unfamiliarity of it all like a physical weight, simply ordered a glass of water. Marco raised an eyebrow almost imperceptibly. "Keeping a clear head for the battle ahead, Reverend? Smart." He smiled that dazzling smile again, but this time Amelia saw it for what it was: a perfectly polished weapon. Beatrice had been right. This world was all teeth. And they were just getting started.The bubbles rose in Marco’s flute like a tiny, effervescent applause. He took a delicate sip, his dark eyes fixed on Amelia over the rim of the glass. "It's a brave move, I'll give you that," he continued, his voice dropping into a conspiratorial tone. "The whole reverend thing. A gimmick, sure, but a brilliant one. The network must be ecstatic. It's a narrative people can get behind. The spirit versus the flesh, or whatever." He gestured vaguely at the Hollywood scene around them. "People eat that stuff up. It sets you apart."

The word "gimmick" landed like a stone in the pit of her stomach. He had taken her life's work, her calling, the very core of her identity, and reduced it to a marketing strategy. A part of her wanted to recoil, to explain the years of seminary, the quiet moments holding the hands of the dying, the profound joy of baptizing a newborn. But she saw the trap in his words. To get defensive was to lose. Instead, she offered him a small, placid smile, the kind she usually reserved for particularly trying parish council meetings. "I suppose you could see it that way," she said, her voice even and calm. "But my clerical collar is no more a gimmick than your charm is, Marco. We all wear the uniform that gets us through the day."

A sharp, unexpected snort of laughter came from the corner of the couch. Skyler finally looked up from their phone, a smirk playing on their lips, heavily outlined in black. "Damn," they said, their voice a surprisingly low, gravelly alto. "She got you there, pretty boy." They shoved their phone into a pocket of their ripped jeans and leaned forward, directing their attention to Amelia for the first time. "I saw your tape. That version of 'I Put a Spell on You' was sick. Like, actually good. Not that churchy crap I was expecting." The compliment was wrapped in so much youthful cynicism it was almost unrecognizable, but it was genuine. In that moment, Skyler wasn't "the Scream," the punk caricature; they were just a kid who liked music.

Marco, for the first time, looked momentarily flustered. He recovered with a practiced laugh, raising his hands in mock surrender. "Alright, alright, I'm outnumbered. My apologies, Reverend. It seems my charm, as you call it, needs a tune-up." He winked at Amelia, a slick attempt to reclaim control, but the dynamic in the cabana had subtly shifted. An invisible thread of connection, however thin, had been strung between the reverend and the punk kid, leaving the crooner on the outside. Chad, ever the producer, looked thrilled by the flicker of drama. "See! This is what I'm talking about! Fire and ice! You guys are going to be incredible on camera together."

Paisley, the talent liaison, chose that moment to reappear, tablet in hand, her expression one of cheerful, organized panic. "Okay, team! First-day logistics!" she chirped, and the brief moment of human connection evaporated. "We have a 6 a.m. call time tomorrow. That's a car waiting for you in the lobby. 6 a.m., people, not 6:01. We go straight to the studio for vocal warm-ups with Debra, she's a legend, she works with literally everyone. Then it's two hours of wardrobe and styling, followed by your first round of EPK interviews." She took a breath. "After lunch, Marco, you have a choreography session for your number. Skyler, you're with the band to work through your arrangement. And Amy," she said, her eyes finding Amelia's, "we have you scheduled for a session on stage presence and media training. Just to get you comfortable with the scale of the show. Any questions?"

Amelia's mind reeled. The schedule was a relentless assault, a battle plan for an invasion she hadn't yet agreed to fight. Media training? Stage presence? It sounded like they wanted to sand down her edges, to remold her into a shape that would fit a television screen. She felt a surge of longing for the slow, familiar pace of her life in Gainesville, for the quiet mornings spent writing a sermon, the biggest logistical challenge being a faulty printer. She simply shook her head, the word "no" catching in her throat. The machine was in motion now, and she was just a cog, expected to turn when and how she was told.

Later, back in the silent, white expanse of her room, Amelia stood at the floor-to-ceiling window, the city lights below a vast, indifferent galaxy. The initial excitement that had carried her from Florida had been ground down by the realities of the evening, replaced by a heavy, anxious weariness. The Skybar, with its casual cruelties and calculated performances, had shown her the truth of Beatrice’s words. It was a world of teeth, and they were all so sharp. She saw her reflection faintly in the glass, a solitary figure in a plain black dress, looking small and out of place against the sprawling backdrop of the city. She looked tired. She looked lost.

Turning away from the view, her eyes fell on the worn leather of her Book of Common Prayer on the nightstand. It was a piece of home, an artifact from a truer world. She picked it up, the familiar weight of it a comfort in her hand. Sinking onto the edge of the enormous, sterile bed, she let the book fall open to the Compline, the final prayers for the end of the day. She began to read the ancient words aloud, her voice a quiet murmur in the stillness of the room. "Keep watch, dear Lord, with those who work, or watch, or weep this night, and give your angels charge over those who sleep." The cadence of the prayer was a balm, a rhythm that was older and deeper than the synthetic beat of the music at the bar. The prayer was not a performance. It asked for nothing but peace. It promised nothing but presence. As she spoke the words into the empty, luxurious space, Amelia felt a small, crucial part of herself click back into place. The singer was in Hollywood, yes. But the Reverend was here, too. And she would need her.The insistent, digital chirping of the hotel alarm at 5:30 a.m. felt like a personal affront. For a moment, disoriented in the pre-dawn gloom of the white room, Amelia thought it was a fire alarm. Then reality crashed in, cold and immediate. 6 a.m. call time. She swung her legs out of the enormous bed, the plush carpet a small, surprising comfort under her feet. The city outside was a muted tapestry of grey and distant, sleeping lights, a far cry from the glittering spectacle of the previous night. She felt the dull throb of sleep deprivation behind her eyes, a familiar sensation from late-night hospital vigils, but this felt different, tinged not with pastoral duty but with a secular, high-stakes anxiety.

In the stark white bathroom, under lights so bright they felt like an interrogation, she looked at her reflection. She looked like a woman who had been flown across a continent and dropped into a life that was not her own. She thought of Marco’s word: gimmick. Today, she would be tested. Today, they would try to shape her. Reaching for her bag, she pulled out the stiff white rectangle of her collar. Her fingers, practiced and sure, fastened it around her neck. It felt less like armor this morning and more like an anchor, a solid, tangible piece of her identity in a world that felt fluid and false. She chose a simple black shirt and black pants, the closest thing she had to a uniform. If they were going to see her as the singing vicar, they were going to see the whole vicar.

Down in the lobby, the atmosphere of curated cool had been replaced by a hushed, purposeful silence. A different black SUV was waiting, purring expectantly at the curb. The driver, a large man with a kind face who introduced himself as Sal, simply nodded at her collar. "Morning, Reverend," he said, his voice a warm, welcome rumble. The drive through the waking city was surreal. The famous streets were nearly empty, populated only by delivery trucks, street sweepers, and the solitary figures of early-morning runners. Sal navigated the freeways with an unspoken expertise, the city unfolding around them in shades of orange and pink as the sun began to rise behind the hazy eastern mountains. He didn't speak, and Amelia was grateful for the silence. It gave her a moment to breathe, to murmur a quick, silent prayer for the day ahead, a simple appeal for grace under pressure.

The studio lot was not in Hollywood but in Burbank, a sprawling, functional city-within-a-city of beige soundstages that looked like colossal packing crates. After passing through a security gate where Sal flashed a pass, they pulled up to a building marked ‘Stage 4’. The moment the door opened, the carefully constructed peace of the morning was shattered. The inside was a hive of frantic, focused activity. People with headsets and clipboards strode purposefully through a labyrinth of cables and lighting equipment, their voices a low, urgent hum. The air smelled strongly of coffee, sawdust, and something faintly electrical. A young man with a headset immediately detached himself from a group and hurried toward her. "Amelia! Great, you're here! I'm Kevin. Right this way, Debra's waiting."

He led her not to a glamorous dressing room, but to a small, soundproofed studio containing little more than a grand piano and a wall of mirrors. A woman with a cascade of silver hair pulled back in a severe bun sat at the keyboard, her back ramrod straight. She didn't turn as they entered. "Leave us, Kevin," she said, her voice possessing a calm authority that cut through the surrounding chaos. As the door clicked shut, she turned on the piano bench. Her face was a map of fine lines, and her eyes, a piercing blue, seemed to take in everything about Amelia in a single, unblinking assessment. This was Debra, the legend. "Reverend Amelia Cartwright," she said. It wasn't a question. "I've heard a lot about you. Forget all of it. I don't care about your story, I care about your larynx. Sit."

Amelia sat on a stool near the piano, feeling like a student called to the principal's office. Debra's fingers danced over the keys, playing a simple, ascending scale. "Sing," she commanded. Amelia opened her mouth and followed the notes, her voice still thick with sleep. Debra stopped her after a few bars. "No. Not from the church. Not from the television. From here." She tapped her own sternum with two fingers. "That sound you made on the tape, the one where you almost broke the microphone? That came from your gut. It was trained in a gospel choir, wasn't it? And you listened to a lot of blues growing up." Amelia, startled by the accuracy, could only nod. "I thought so," Debra said, a flicker of a smile touching her lips. "It's a wonderful, dangerous instrument you have. You've learned to control it for hymns, to fill a sanctuary without hurting yourself. But you haven't really let it go in a long time. You're afraid of it. We're not going to be afraid of it in here." For the next hour, there was no talk of television, competition, or narratives. There was only breath, scales, resonance, and power. Debra pushed her, challenged her, and for the first time since arriving, Amelia felt a spark of genuine joy. It was the joy of the work, the craft.

The peace of the vocal session was promptly obliterated by the wardrobe department. It was a vast room, a riot of color and texture, with rolling racks of clothes that seemed to stretch on for miles. A man named Antoine, who had a silver streak in his hair and an expression of deep, artistic suffering, circled Amelia like a sculptor assessing a block of marble. "No, no, no," he muttered, waving a dismissive hand at her clerical attire. "It's too on the nose. Too severe. We need to soften it. Give you a halo, not a yoke." He and his assistants began pulling garments from the racks—dresses in flowing cream-colored fabrics, silk blouses in jewel tones, things with ethereal-looking capes. "The network wants 'angelic,'" Antoine explained, "but with a hint of soul. Think Florence Welch officiating a very chic wedding."

He paused, his eyes narrowing on her neck. "And the collar, darling. It will have to go for the performance. It reads terribly on camera. Flattens the light, creates shadows. We can give you a beautiful necklace, something that catches the light." This was it. The first real push. Amelia stood very still amidst the whirlwind of silk and sequins. "The collar stays," she said, her voice quiet but firm. Antoine sighed dramatically. "But it's a costume choice, and I am the costume designer." Amelia met his gaze, her expression unwavering. "With respect, Antoine, it's not a costume. It's my life. It's who I am. If you want Amelia Cartwright, you get her. All of her." There was a tense silence, the assistants freezing with armfuls of fabric. Antoine stared at her, then a slow smile spread across his face. "Alright, Reverend," he said, with a newfound respect in his tone. "Challenge accepted. If the collar stays, then we make the collar fashion." The battle was small, but Amelia felt a surge of victory. It wasn't just about a piece of plastic; it was about not letting them edit her soul for prime time.The victory with Antoine left Amelia feeling buoyed, as if she’d successfully defended a small but crucial piece of sovereign territory. That feeling, however, began to dissipate as Kevin, the headset-wearing guide, led her through another series of identical corridors to a room designated for media training. The space was set up like a miniature television studio, with several cameras pointed at a small, brightly lit stage where three chairs were arranged in a gentle arc. Marco was already there, lounging in one of the chairs and chatting easily with a woman who held a tablet and radiated an aura of terrifying competence. Skyler was conspicuously absent.

"Amy, perfect! This is Jocelyn," Chad said, appearing from the shadows of the control booth with his signature explosive energy. "Jocelyn is our artist development guru. She's going to help you all shape your stories for the press. She's the best." Jocelyn gave Amelia a smile that was wide but didn't reach her eyes. She was whip-thin, dressed in sharp-angled black, and looked like she subsisted entirely on espresso and the weaknesses of others. "Reverend. A pleasure. We have so much to work with here. The narrative is fantastic." The word ‘narrative’ again. In this world, it seemed, life wasn't lived, it was curated.

Just then, Skyler ambled in, headphones clamped over their ears, moving with a deliberate slowness that was a clear act of passive resistance. They slumped into the empty chair furthest from Marco, not acknowledging anyone. Jocelyn’s professional smile tightened by a millimeter. "Welcome, Skyler. Glad you could join us. Now, let's begin. The finale isn't just about the final song. It's about the final story. The audience needs to fall in love with you before you even sing a note. Marco, let's start with you. Give me your sixty-second elevator pitch. Who are you?"

Marco leaned forward, his posture a study in relaxed confidence. "Well, Jocelyn," he began, his voice a smooth baritone, "I'm a man who believes in the classics. In a world of digital noise, I want to bring back a little old-school romance, a little Sinatra, a little Dean Martin. An awkward silence descended upon the stage. Amelia felt a small surge of gratitude for the unexpected, and likely unintentional, rescue. That evening, exhausted and emotionally frayed, Amelia sat on the edge of her bed and dialed the number for the church office. "Just sing the song, Amy," Beatrice said, her voice suddenly serious. "Don't let those people with their white teeth and empty heads get into yours. You just open your mouth and sing the way you do. The rest is just noise." "Thank you, Bea," Amelia whispered, her throat tight. "Now go to bed," Beatrice commanded. "You'll need your strength to smite the Philistines." When she hung up, the white room felt a little less sterile. The conversation had been like a cool drink of water in the desert. The backstage area of Stage 4 had transformed from a frantic hive into a full-blown military operation. Chad was the first to find her, his face flushed with victory and champagne. “Amy! You were magnificent! Staggering! The numbers from the final segment are through the roof. People went crazy. Later, as the party began to thin, a figure approached her corner. It was Silas Blackwood, the legendary producer, holding two glasses of sparkling water. He handed one to her, his movements precise and deliberate. They stood in silence for a moment, watching the city below. "Jocelyn tried to package you," he said, his voice a low, thoughtful rumble. "Chad tried to brand you. Dex tried to choreograph you. And you politely, and firmly, told them all to go to hell." Amelia choked on a sip of water, and Silas actually smiled, a rare, crinkling expression that transformed his stern face. "I've been in this business for forty years, Reverend. I’ve seen singers who can hit the notes and I’ve seen performers who can work a crowd. It’s a rare thing to see an artist who can stand still and tell the truth."

He swirled the bubbles in his glass. "I don't care about a Christmas special. What I care about is that voice. I want to record it. Not here," he said with a dismissive wave at the glittering city. "I'm thinking a small studio in Nashville or Muscle Shoals. Just you, a piano, a B-3 organ, and a few of the best session players alive. No gimmicks, no narratives. We record a dozen songs. Old spirituals, some Sam Cooke, maybe a few of those blues your daddy liked. We make a record for the ages. One album. No tour, no press junkets, unless you want them. We just make the art." The offer hung in the air, a thing of astonishing weight and beauty. It was everything she could have dreamed of, stripped of everything she feared. It wasn't a temptation to abandon her life; it was an invitation to enrich it. "I… I don't know what to say, Silas," she stammered. "Say you'll think about it," he replied. "Go home. Stand in your church. Talk to your God. My number is on the card." He slipped a plain, heavy-stock business card into her hand and, with a slight nod, was gone.

The flight back to Florida was the reverse image of her arrival. She was in a middle seat in coach, wedged between a sleeping salesman and a young mother trying to entertain a restless toddler. The glamour of first class felt like a dream she’d once had. Yet, Amelia felt a deep and abiding contentment. The frantic energy of Los Angeles slowly receded with every mile, replaced by the humid, familiar pull of home. She watched the clouds, no longer seeing an unknowable future but the comfortable, cherished patterns of her own life. When the flight attendant came by with the beverage cart, she ordered a ginger ale, and it tasted crisp and perfect. She didn't open her Book of Common Prayer. She didn't need to. The peace she sought was already in her heart.

Gainesville Regional Airport was blessedly small and quiet. As she walked into the tiny baggage claim area, she saw Beatrice standing by the door, arms crossed, her expression a carefully neutral mask. There was no banner, no cheering congregation. There was only Bea, solid and real. Amelia felt a surge of affection so strong it almost brought her to tears. She walked over, and Beatrice, in a shocking breach of her own protocol, gave her a brief, stiff hug. “Well,” Beatrice said, stepping back and immediately reassuming her customary posture. “You’re not blonde and you’re not carrying a tiny dog. I consider the entire venture a resounding success.” Amelia laughed, a sound of pure relief.

In the car, Beatrice’s old, reliable sedan that smelled faintly of tea and disinfectant, Amelia watched the familiar landscape of Archer Road roll by. The live oaks, draped in Spanish moss, felt like old friends welcoming her back. "Mrs. Higgins has already prepared a three-page critique of your final performance," Beatrice informed her matter-of-factly. "She felt the blue dress was 'a tad ostentatious for a woman of the cloth,' but conceded that your breath control was 'exemplary.'" Amelia smiled. "Of course she did." The normalcy of it was a balm. She hesitated for a moment, then reached into her purse and pulled out Silas Blackwood's card. "I got an offer, Bea." She explained the proposal—the album, Nashville, the old spirituals. Beatrice listened in silence, her eyes fixed on the road. When Amelia finished, Bea was quiet for a full thirty seconds. "Muscle Shoals," she said finally, as if tasting the words. "They had a fine rhythm section there in the sixties. Aretha recorded there." Amelia looked at her secretary, astonished. Beatrice sniffed. "I don't live in a cave, Amelia. I read." She glanced at the business card. "Well, I suppose making a proper record is more dignified than being humiliated on national television. What did you tell him?" Amelia looked out the window at the sinking sun. "I told him I had to come home first." Beatrice nodded once, a gesture of profound approval. "Good," she said. "First things first."

The first thing was St. Jude’s. She asked Beatrice to drop her off there before taking her home. The evening light was casting long shadows across the yard, and the air was thick with the familiar song of cicadas. She pushed open the heavy oak doors and stepped inside. The sanctuary was cool and quiet, smelling of wax and old hymnals and peace. The last rays of sun filtered through the stained-glass window of St. Jude, turning the dust motes into a swirl of jewels. It was exactly as she had left it. She walked down the stone aisle, her sensible shoes making soft, welcoming sounds, and stood in the very spot where this whole impossible journey had begun. She was not the same woman who had stood here just over a week ago. She was less afraid of the world, and more certain of her place in it. The lost cause wasn't the singing; it was the idea that she had to choose. She didn't. She could be both. The Reverend Amelia Cartwright, a woman with a voice too big for her body, was home. And she had a record to make. On her own terms. She threw her head back, not to laugh or to cry, but simply to breathe in the dusty, sacred air of her own life, and it was the sweetest thing she had ever known.The first thing Amelia noticed on Wednesday morning was the sound of a mockingbird, perched on the power line outside her bedroom window, running through its entire chaotic repertoire. It was a sound so deeply, fundamentally Gainesville that it almost made her laugh. There were no sirens, no distant hum of the freeway, just the manic genius of a single bird and the low rumble of her own refrigerator. She got out of bed, her feet finding the familiar cool of the worn pine floorboards, and padded into her small kitchen. The air was thick with the promise of afternoon rain, a smell of damp earth and blooming jasmine. It was the antithesis of the dry, gasoline-tinged air of Los Angeles. As she measured out coffee grounds into the filter of her cheap drip coffee maker, she looked out at her overgrown backyard, a riot of green that was perpetually on the verge of becoming a jungle. It was messy and imperfect and profoundly hers.

Later that morning, sitting in her creaky office chair at St. Jude’s, the sense of homecoming was made even more concrete by the formidable stack of mail Beatrice had placed squarely in the center of her desk. It was a monument to mundane reality: utility bills, advertisements for new choir robes, a newsletter from the diocese, and, on top of it all, a thick envelope of heavy cream-colored stationery, sealed with a wax stamp of what appeared to be a schnauzer. Beatrice, who was meticulously organizing the donation pledges from the bake sale, nodded toward it. “That’s from Mrs. Higgins,” she said. “Her official review. She had it delivered by courier this morning. I believe the word ‘exemplary’ made an appearance, which, from her, is the equivalent of a canonization.” Amelia picked up the letter, feeling its weight. The peacock-blue dress may have been seen by millions, but it was this three-page, single-spaced critique that truly signified her return.

“So,” Beatrice said, not looking up from her ledger. “Have you given any more thought to the record producer and his blank check?” She made ‘record producer’ sound like a particularly unsavory species of insect. “It’s one thing to take a week’s leave for a television spectacle. It’s quite another to embark on a new career. This parish, you may have noticed, does not run itself. The plumbing in the men’s room is making that gurgling sound again, and the youth group wants to know if they can paint a mural of the loaves and fishes on the fellowship hall wall. They’ve submitted sketches. It looks more like piranhas attacking a baguette.” Amelia smiled, the familiar rhythm of church problems a comforting balm. “I know, Bea. I’m not abandoning my post.” She placed Silas Blackwood’s card on her desk, next to Mrs. Higgins’s letter. The two objects seemed to represent the two halves of her life, no longer at war, but sitting in quiet, curious conversation. “But it’s an opportunity. Not just for me. For the music.” Beatrice finally looked up, her sharp eyes meeting Amelia’s. “The music was doing just fine here every Sunday morning. But,” she sighed, a small concession, “I suppose the world has more need of it than just us. Just don’t expect me to handle the logistics of a Nashville commute. My jurisdiction ends at the Florida-Georgia line.”

That Sunday, the church was fuller than it had been on any Easter in recent memory. People packed the pews, spilling into the overflow chairs Beatrice had begrudgingly set up in the narthex. There were the familiar faces of her flock, their expressions a mixture of pride, curiosity, and a touch of proprietary ownership. But there were also strangers, people from town who had likely never set foot in St. Jude’s, drawn by the novelty of having a local celebrity, a singing vicar, in their midst. As Amelia stood in the sacristy, pulling on her familiar white vestments over her simple black cassock, she felt a tremor of nerves that rivaled what she’d felt backstage in Hollywood. This audience was scarier. They were her people. Their judgment mattered more.

When she walked to the pulpit to deliver her sermon, a hush fell over the sanctuary. She looked out at their faces—at old Mr. Abernathy, whose expression was guarded; at the young families in the front, their children squirming impatiently; at the new faces in the back, their expressions expectant. She set aside her prepared notes on the Gospel of Mark. “I imagine some of you are here today because you saw me on a television show,” she began, her voice clear and calm, carrying through the still air without the aid of a microphone. “You saw the lights, and the sequins, and the famous people. And it was all as bewildering and wonderful as it looked. But I have to confess, the most important performance of my week was not on that stage. It’s right here. It’s always right here.” She let her gaze travel across the room, meeting as many eyes as she could.

“We all have gifts,” she continued, her voice gaining the familiar cadence of her pastoral rhythm. “Some of us have a gift for baking lemon bars that can bring a grown man to his knees. Some of us have a gift for balancing a church budget down to the last penny. Some have the gift of a listening ear, or a strong back, or a kind word. And some of us, through no virtue of our own, are given a voice. For years, I thought my voice was a gift intended only for these walls, to be used in the service of this congregation. But this last week, I have been wondering. What if a gift isn’t meant just for the people we know? What if a calling isn’t to a single place, but to a single purpose, wherever it may lead? What if a hymn sung in a church in Gainesville could become a prayer heard in a stranger’s kitchen a thousand miles away?” She looked down at the pulpit, then back up at her flock. "I have been given an opportunity to record some of that music. Some of those old, powerful songs of faith and hope. I don’t know where that path leads. But I know that I cannot walk it alone. I would need your blessing. Your patience. And your prayers. Because St. Jude’s-in-the-Swamp is not my job. It is my home. And this… this is my family.”

A profound silence followed her words, the kind of quiet that is full of thought and feeling. Then, from the third row, old Mr. Abernathy, the one who had muttered about “worldly temptations,” slowly, deliberately, began to clap. It was a sparse, rhythmic sound in the stillness. Then another person joined in, and another, until the entire sanctuary was filled not with a roar of applause like the one in Hollywood, but with a warm, steady, heartfelt ovation. It was the sound of a family giving its blessing. During the coffee hour that followed, Mr. Abernathy shook her hand, his grip firm. "You did us proud, Reverend," he said, his voice gruff with emotion. "You go sing those hymns. The world needs to hear 'em." Amelia’s heart felt so full it might burst. She had her answer. The path was clear.The Monday after her sermon felt like the first day of a new season. The air was washed clean, the humidity a familiar promise, and the business of St. Jude’s resumed its steady, comforting rhythm. Amelia sat at her desk, the phone receiver cool and heavy in her hand, Silas Blackwood’s card lying face-up beside the blotter. She had prayed on it, she had slept on it, and she had received the unequivocal blessing of her flock. There was no more uncertainty, only a quiet, thrumming nerve of anticipation. With a deep breath that was part prayer and part preparation, she dialed the Los Angeles number, her finger steady on the keypad. It was an act of faith, no different than stepping up to the pulpit.

Silas answered on the second ring, his voice devoid of any receptionist or automated filtering. "Blackwood," he said, the single word as calm and solid as a bedrock. “Silas, it’s Amelia Cartwright.” There was no need to say more. A brief, knowing silence hummed over the line. “Reverend,” he replied, and she could almost hear the slight, respectful nod in his voice. “I was hoping you’d call. Is it a yes?” Amelia looked out her office window at the old cypress tree, its branches reaching toward the sky. “It’s a yes,” she said, her own voice firm. “Good,” Silas said, the word conveying a deep satisfaction. “Then we begin. I’m booking a studio in Nashville for the first two weeks of next month. Small place, great sound, no distractions. I’ll send my assistant the details. All I need from you is a list. Twenty or thirty songs that live in your bones. Old spirituals, gospel standards, the blues your father loved. We’ll whittle it down when you get here. Just bring the music and your voice.” That was it. No talk of contracts or advances, no mention of marketing or brands. It was a conversation between two artists about the work.

When she hung up, the quiet of the office seemed to buzz with a new potential. The path ahead had suddenly become a tangible line on a map, leading straight to Nashville. A moment later, Beatrice entered, carrying two mugs of coffee. She placed one on Amelia’s desk without a word, her movements precise. She didn’t need to ask; her sharp eyes took in Amelia’s expression, the phone, the business card still on the desk. "So you've done it," Beatrice stated, not a question but a conclusion. "You've officially joined the circus." Amelia smiled, taking a sip of the strong, hot coffee. "I think this might be a different circus, Bea." Beatrice sniffed, a sound of profound skepticism. "There’s only one circus, Amelia. It just has different tents. I’ve already taken the liberty of calling Reverend Miller from Christ the King in Ocala. He can cover the first two Sundays of the month, but I must warn you, his sermons have a tendency to run long and he’s allergic to cats, so you’ll need to deep-clean the rectory before he arrives. The work, as they say, goes on." The sheer, wonderful pragmatism of Beatrice’s concerns was the most grounding force Amelia could imagine.

That evening, propelled by a new sense of purpose, Amelia went not to her prayer book but to the deep, dusty closet in her spare bedroom. Inside, under a stack of old blankets, were two cardboard boxes she hadn’t opened in years. They held the remnants of her father's life, and at their heart, his most prized possessions: his record collection. She lifted the first crate, the smell of aging cardboard and vinyl filling her senses. It was a smell as evocative and comforting as church incense. She carried the box into her living room and knelt on the floor, pulling out the albums one by one, their covers like portals to another time. There was Etta James, fierce and defiant on the cover of ‘At Last!’. There was the stoic, handsome face of Sam Cooke, and the joyful, triumphant gaze of Mahalia Jackson. Muddy Waters, Howlin' Wolf, Sister Rosetta Tharpe with her electric guitar. It was a hymnal of a different sort, a catechism of soul, pain, and transcendence.

She slid a record from its sleeve, the heavy black vinyl cool and solid in her hands. It was Mahalia Jackson’s ‘Newport 1958’. Placing it on the turntable, she lowered the needle, and the room filled with the gentle hiss and crackle of anticipation. Then, the sound emerged. Mahalia’s voice, a force of nature, both thunderous and tender, filled the small house. It was a voice that didn't just sing notes; it built monuments out of them. Amelia closed her eyes, letting the music wash over her. She was a child again, sitting on the floor of their small house while her father listened, his eyes closed just as hers were now, a glass of whiskey sweating on the table beside him. He had found his church in these records, his salvation in these voices. In that moment, listening to the raw, consecrated power of Mahalia’s "Trouble of the World," Amelia understood her task. She wasn't just making a record. She was continuing her father's prayer.The days that followed were a deep, resonant hum of preparation. Amelia’s small living room transformed into a sanctuary of song, the floor a mosaic of album covers, open hymnals, and legal pads filled with her looping, cursive script. The process of creating her list for Silas was a kind of archeology, an excavation of her own heart. She would spend hours just listening, letting the needle find the groove, allowing the voices of the past to fill the quiet spaces of her house. She rediscovered the raw, electric grit of Sister Rosetta Tharpe, the woman who played her guitar in front of the altar and made holy music that sounded thrillingly profane. She ran her fingers over the liner notes of a dog-eared Odetta album, her voice a deep, resonant bell of sorrow and strength that Amelia remembered shaking the very walls of their house on stormy nights.

Each song was a key, unlocking a specific memory. She wrote down "Trouble in Mind," a slow, mournful blues standard, and was instantly transported to a Saturday afternoon, watching her father painstakingly clean a fish on a sheet of newspaper, humming the melody under his breath, a sound of such profound, unspoken weariness it had made her child's heart ache. She added "His Eye Is on the Sparrow," and she was no longer in her living room but standing at the bedside of a dying woman from her parish, holding her hand and singing the hymn softly as the woman’s breathing grew shallow, the words a promise of care in the face of the ultimate unknown. The list grew, a strange and sacred document that blurred the lines between the juke joint and the chancel, between her father’s whiskey-soaked regrets and her own hard-won faith. They were all songs of survival, declarations that even in the deepest darkness, a voice could rise, a chord could be struck, and a soul could endure.

Beatrice, entering the rectory with the week’s grocery delivery, surveyed the vinyl-strewn living room with a look of deep suspicion. "It appears a record store has exploded in here," she observed, placing a carton of milk on the counter with a decisive thud. Amelia, sitting on the floor surrounded by open books, looked up with a distracted smile. “I’m making the list for Silas,” she explained, holding up a record by The Staple Singers. “Have you ever really listened to Mavis Staples, Bea? Her voice isn’t just notes. It’s… it’s conviction.” Beatrice peered at the album cover, at the family of singers looking back with serious, soulful eyes. "She’s the one who sang about respecting yourself, isn't she?" Beatrice said, her tone matter-of-fact. "A perfectly sound theological and practical position. Far more useful than some of those dirges you favor." The comment, so unexpectedly astute, so perfectly Beatrice, made Amelia laugh. Her secretary’s support was never soft or sentimental; it was practical, sharp, and, in its own way, as solid and reliable as the ground beneath her feet.

Her departure for Nashville was the quiet opposite of the boisterous, banner-waving send-off to Los Angeles. This time, there was no crowd, no pimento cheese sandwiches. It was just Beatrice, driving her to the small Gainesville airport in the pre-dawn quiet. The air was cool and damp. Beatrice didn’t say much, her hands gripping the steering wheel as if navigating a particularly treacherous theological argument. At the curb, she finally turned to Amelia, her face uncharacteristically serious in the dim glow of the dashboard lights. "I have packed a thermos of Earl Grey tea and a bag of your preferred ginger snaps in your carry-on," she announced, as if issuing military orders. "And I have spoken to Reverend Miller. He understands that under no circumstances is he to alter the flower arrangement schedule." She paused, her gaze unwavering. "Do not let them make you sound… shiny, Amelia. Your voice has grit. It has peat and loam in it. Don’t let them polish it away." It was the most poetic thing Amelia had ever heard her say. Impulsively, Amelia leaned over and hugged her. "Thank you, Bea," she whispered. "For everything." Beatrice endured the hug for precisely three seconds before patting her briskly on the back. "Alright, alright. Go on, then. Go make your joyful noise."

Nashville was not Hollywood. Instead of skinny palm trees and sun-bleached billboards, the landscape from the taxi window was one of rolling green hills, solid brick buildings, and a sky that seemed softer, somehow closer to the earth. The studio Silas had chosen was not a gleaming high-rise but a nondescript, single-story building on a quiet side street south of the main Music Row drag. It had a faded red door and windows that were bricked in. It looked less like a studio and more like a secret, a place that didn't need to advertise what it held within. Amelia paid the driver and stood for a moment on the sidewalk, her small suitcase in one hand, her guitar case in the other. A low, beautiful moan of a Hammond B-3 organ seeped through the brick walls, a sound so soulful and welcome it felt like an invitation. Taking a breath, she pushed open the red door and stepped inside. The room was dark, woody, and warm, lit by a few dim lamps and the glow of vacuum tubes on vintage equipment. The air smelled of old wood, coffee, and ozone. It felt less like a business and more like a workshop, a place of craft and history. In the center of the room, a small group of men were gathered around the organ, lost in a slow, meandering blues progression. Silas Blackwood detached himself from the shadows, a mug of coffee in his hand. He smiled, a genuine, welcoming expression. "Reverend," he said, his voice a low rumble. "Welcome. We were just warming up."The men looked up as Silas spoke, their playing tapering off into a final, shimmering chord that hung in the air like a question. They were not the slick, handsome performers of Los Angeles. The man at the Hammond B-3 organ, who Amelia instinctively knew must be Spoon, was a broad-shouldered man with hands the size of dinner plates and a kind, weary face that looked like it had seen the inside of a thousand smoky clubs. The bass player, Clay, was lean and wiry, with a salt-and-pepper beard and watchful eyes. The drummer, Russell, was younger, with a quiet, almost shy demeanor, his hands resting lightly on his snare. They nodded at her, their greetings a series of low, respectful murmurs. "Ma'am." "Pleasure." There was no mention of the television show, no flicker of recognition of her brief, fleeting fame. They were assessing her not as a celebrity, but as a musician, a potential collaborator. Their respect was not a given; it was a currency to be earned.

“Amelia, this is Spoon, Clay, and Russell,” Silas said, completing the introductions. “They’ve played on more records that matter than either of us could count.” He gestured toward the center of the room, where a vintage microphone stood waiting like a silent congregant. “No glass between us here, Reverend. We’re all in the same room. We breathe the same air, we find the sound together. So, where would you like to begin?” He stepped back, melting into the shadows near the large mixing console, his role shifting from host to observer. The room was hers. Amelia’s heart gave a single, hard thump of nervous excitement. She looked at the three men, who were watching her with patient, professional curiosity. She thought of her father, of the blues that had been his prayer book. She had to start there. “How about we try ‘Trouble in Mind’?” she asked, her voice a little softer than she’d intended. “In C.” Spoon’s hands immediately found the keys, and he played a slow, searching introductory chord, a sound as thick and mournful as a foggy morning. Clay watched her for a beat, then his fingers found the thick strings of his upright bass, and a note bloomed in the room, a low, resonant pulse that felt like a heartbeat. Russell joined in with the whisper-soft sweep of brushes on the snare.

Amelia took her place at the microphone, closing her eyes. She didn't sing for Silas or the seasoned musicians. She sang for the ghosts in the room, for her father, for herself. The first words emerged not as a performance, but as a confession, her voice imbued with that peat and loam Beatrice had spoken of. It was a sound that had grit in it, the sound of a soul that had known sorrow. The musicians didn't follow her; they moved with her, creating a seamless, breathing entity. Spoon’s organ didn’t compete with her voice but supported it, swelling gently in the spaces between her lines like an amen. Clay’s bass provided a solid, grounding foundation, a path for her to walk on, while Russell’s drums were the quiet, insistent rhythm of a troubled heart. They played through the song once, the music a slow, aching conversation. When the final chord faded into a perfect silence, no one spoke. Amelia opened her eyes. Spoon was looking at her, a slow smile spreading across his face. He simply nodded once, a gesture of profound musical respect. “Alright now,” he murmured, his voice a low gravel. “That’ll preach.”

That first song unlocked everything. The initial, unspoken test had been passed, and the polite professionalism in the room warmed into a comfortable, easy camaraderie. The days that followed blurred into one long, continuous act of creation, fueled by endless cups of strong black coffee and a shared, unspoken language. The outside world, with its demands and distractions, ceased to exist. Their only reality was the warm, woody room and the universe of sound they were building within it. They moved through her list like a pilgrimage. They transformed "His Eye Is on the Sparrow" from a simple hymn into a quiet, meditative prayer, her voice weaving through the sparse accompaniment like a thread of light. On a fiery version of Sister Rosetta Tharpe’s “Didn’t It Rain,” Amelia shed her pastoral gentleness and let the raw, joyful power of her voice loose, her delivery pushing the band, who responded with a driving, ferocious energy that left them all breathless and grinning at the end. Silas presided over it all from his perch at the console, more of a trusted guide than a director. His interventions were rare and surgically precise. “Clay, let’s have the bass walk a little more on that second verse,” or “Reverend, try that line again, but sing it like you’re telling a secret.” He wasn’t imposing a vision; he was helping them uncover the one that already existed within the music.

On the third afternoon, they decided to tackle “A Change Is Gonna Come.” The air in the room shifted, a quiet reverence descending upon them. They all knew the weight of the song. This wasn't the version she had sung for the cameras in Los Angeles, a defiant statement against a backdrop of spectacle. This had to be the source, the river itself. They worked out an arrangement that was even more spare than the one on the show, built around the steady, river-like pulse of Clay’s bass and the mournful, atmospheric swells of Spoon’s organ. They did a few rehearsals, feeling their way into the song’s deep, sorrowful architecture. Then Silas’s voice came through the speakers. “I think we’re ready. Let’s try and get one from top to bottom.” He called it a take, but it felt more like a consecration. Amelia stood at the microphone, the headphones feeling like a confessor’s screen. She sang, and the story poured out of her, no longer a performance but an embodiment. The weariness of the opening verses felt bone-deep, the memory of her father’s struggles tangling with the song’s universal lament. When she reached the bridge, the pain of betrayal was not a theatrical choice but a palpable ache in her voice.

She felt a presence in the room that was more than just the four musicians. It was the weight of history, the spirit of Sam Cooke, the echo of her father’s longing for a change he would never live to see. All of it flowed into her, and through her, into the microphone. As she sang the final, declarative lines, her voice soared, not with the force of a competitor trying to win, but with the unshakeable certainty of a prophet delivering testimony. She held the last note, her eyes shut tight, her hands clenched at her sides, pouring every last ounce of her hope, her faith, and her sorrow into that single, sustained sound. When it finally faded, the silence that fell was absolute, a sacred, shimmering void. No one moved. No one breathed. The only sound was the faint hum of the vintage amplifiers. After a long moment, the talkback button clicked, and Silas’s voice, quiet and thick with emotion, filled their headphones. “Okay,” he said softly. “Let’s just… let’s call it a day.” And in that profound, exhausted quiet, surrounded by the ghosts and the grace notes, Amelia knew she had done more than just sing a song. She had finally, truly, brought it home.The heavy silence in the studio was a sacred thing, a space still vibrating with the ghost of the final note. Russell quietly placed his brushes on a side table, his movements slow and deliberate, as if afraid to disturb the hallowed air. Clay leaned his upright bass against its stand, patting its curved wooden side like the flank of a trusted horse. Spoon simply sat on the organ bench, his large hands resting on his knees, his head bowed. No one looked at each other. They were all still inside the song, adrift in its emotional wake. Amelia felt drained, hollowed out, but also strangely, deeply peaceful, as if she had just completed a long and arduous prayer. Silas’s voice, when it came through the speakers announcing the end of the day, had been a necessary mercy, a gentle release. He emerged from the control room, his usual impassive expression softened by a profound sense of respect. He didn’t offer praise or analysis. He simply walked over to the coffee pot, poured what was left into a mug, and said, “I think we’ve all earned some dinner. There’s a place a few miles from here that serves the best barbecue in Davidson County. My treat.”

The restaurant was not a place of glamour or style. It was a brightly lit, cavernous room with long communal tables and the glorious, smoky haze of a pit barbecue that had been slow-cooking for decades. The five of them slid onto a bench at a long wooden table, the din of families and laughter a welcome, grounding contrast to the intense quiet of the studio. For the first time, Amelia saw the musicians as men outside their craft. Spoon, divested of his organ, became a master storyteller, recounting a near-disastrous gig in Memphis in the seventies with a dry, understated wit that had the whole table laughing. Clay, who was so quiet in the studio, spoke passionately about his daughter’s upcoming science fair project, his eyes lighting up with a father’s pride. They didn’t talk about the record. They didn't talk about the gut-wrenching take of “A Change Is Gonna Come.” They talked about life, about bills and barbecue sauce and the follies of youth. They asked Amelia about Gainesville, about the alligators in Paynes Prairie, about what it was like to counsel grieving widows. They treated her not as a vocalist or a reverend, but simply as a person at their table, sharing a meal. In that noisy, unpretentious restaurant, over plates of smoked brisket and coleslaw, the final wall between them dissolved. They were no longer a singer and her session players. They were a band.

That newfound ease carried them through the rest of the recording sessions, transforming the work from a series of takes into a joyful collaboration. The day after the barbecue, they walked into the studio and, as if by unspoken agreement, decided they needed to make a joyful noise.
