Hesitantly, she picked it up. “Reverend Cartwright speaking,” she said, her voice dropping back into its gentle, pastoral cadence. “Amelia. It’s Silas.” His voice was a calm, low island in the chaotic sea of the afternoon. “I imagine your church secretary is earning her salary today.” “She’s threatening to resign and join a silent order,” Amelia replied, the tension in her shoulders easing at the sound of his steady voice. “I’m not surprised,” he said with a low chuckle. “The Griffin Reed piece has set a fire. I’ve been fielding calls all day. Most of it is noise. People who want to capitalize on the story, who don’t understand the music. I’ve said no to all of them.”

There was a pause, and Amelia could hear him take a breath, as if gathering his thoughts. “But there was one call I had to tell you about. It came this morning from the organizers of the Newport Folk Festival.” The name landed in the quiet office with the weight of history. Newport. The stage where Mahalia Jackson had brought a crowd to tears, where Bob Dylan had gone electric, where Joan Baez had become a legend. It wasn’t just a festival; it was a hallowed ground of American music. “They read Reed’s review,” Silas continued, his voice careful. “They’ve listened to the album. They want you, Amelia. They want you on the main stage. Sunday morning. It’s the traditional gospel slot. The one Mahalia used to have.” The connection was so direct, so resonant with the genesis of the entire project, that Amelia felt a dizzying sense of destiny, a feeling that a circle she hadn’t even known she was drawing was now closing.

“You would have the full band,” Silas went on. “Spoon, Clay, Russell. I’ve already spoken to them. They’ll clear their schedules in a heartbeat if you say the word. Now, listen to me. There is no pressure. This is a bigger stage than you signed up for. If you want to say no, if you want this album to be a beautiful, quiet thing that exists on its own, I will respect that completely. I will make the call and tell them we’re honored, but you’re a full-time minister in Gainesville, Florida, and your work is there. The decision is entirely yours. But I had to ask.” He fell silent, leaving the monumental offer hanging in the air between them. Amelia looked around her small, familiar office—at the crooked drawing of the doves, at the stack of Sunday bulletins waiting to be edited, at the worn spines of the theology books on her shelf. Outside, the late afternoon sun was filtering through the leaves of the old live oak, the world turning a soft, golden color. She had her home. She had her work. And now, a legendary stage, a hallowed ground, was calling her name, offering her a chance to sing her father’s songs and her own prayers in the very place where her heroes had stood. “Amelia?” Silas’s voice was gentle. “Are you still there?” She was there. She was just trying to figure out which way was home.The question Silas had posed—the monumental, life-altering offer to stand on the same stage as Mahalia Jackson—did not feel like a worldly temptation. It felt like a final exam. All the lessons of the past few months, the frantic chaos of Los Angeles and the deep, soulful peace of Nashville, had been leading to this single, terrifying, glorious point. The choice was not between her ministry and her music, she realized as she sat in the deepening twilight of her office. The choice was between fear and faith. Fear would tell her to stay, to protect the quiet life she had reclaimed, to keep her gift safely within the familiar walls of her sanctuary. Fear would whisper that her congregation needed her, that the world outside was too big and too loud, that she had already been blessed enough. But faith, she knew, called her outward. Faith was the belief that her congregation was strong enough to spare her for a weekend. Faith was the trust that the gift she had been given was not meant to be hoarded, but to be shared, poured out, sent into the world to do its work. To refuse this invitation, she understood with a sudden, startling clarity, would not be an act of piety. It would be an act of profound doubt, a failure to trust the very God whose songs she sang.

She stood up and walked into the main office, where Beatrice was methodically re-attaching the telephone cord to the wall jack, her movements precise and full of grim satisfaction. The phone was a vanquished enemy being returned to its post. “I am instituting a new policy,” Beatrice announced without looking up. “All unsolicited calls from individuals in the entertainment industry will be met with a five-minute recording of hymns played on a slightly out-of-tune organ. That should thin the herd.” She straightened up, dusting her hands as if the job were complete. Amelia leaned against the doorframe, a small, knowing smile on her lips. “You might want to leave it unplugged a little while longer, Bea. I have to make a call back to Los Angeles. And then you’ll need to make one to Reverend Miller in Ocala.”

Beatrice froze, her hand hovering over the phone. She turned slowly, her eyes narrowing into slits of pure, concentrated suspicion. “Amelia, what have you done?” Amelia took a breath. “Silas called. He passed on an invitation. For me, and the band—Spoon, Clay, and Russell—to play at the Newport Folk Festival.” She let the name hang in the air. Beatrice’s expression did not change, but a flicker of something, a deep and buried memory of knowledge, passed through her eyes. “Newport,” she repeated, the word sounding foreign and historical on her tongue. Amelia pressed on, laying out the heart of it. “It’s for the Sunday morning gospel set. The one Mahalia Jackson used to sing.” That was the key. Mahalia. A name that transcended show business and entered the realm of history, of undisputed, sanctified genius. Beatrice was silent for a long, heavy moment, her gaze fixed on the middle distance, as if accessing a dusty file deep within her formidable mind. Finally, she looked back at Amelia. “The Newport Folk Festival,” she said again, her voice flat. “It’s in Rhode Island. In July. The humidity is appalling.” She paused, her eyes sharp. “You’ll need to pack light. And for heaven’s sake, remember to hydrate.”

The conversation, so perfectly, wonderfully Beatrice, was the final confirmation Amelia needed. Later that night, she walked into the empty sanctuary, the moonlight painting the pews in stripes of silver and shadow. She didn’t go to pray, but to listen. She stood under the jewel-toned gaze of St. Jude, patron saint of her church and of her own lost causes, and felt the profound, grounding silence of the space. This was her center. This was the source. Newport was not a destination she was leaving for; it was an outpost of this very room. The songs she would sing there were born here, in the quiet joys and sorrows of this place. She was not leaving her ministry behind. She was taking it on the road. Back in her office, she dialed Silas’s number, her heart calm and steady. When he answered, his voice tentative, she didn't hesitate. “Silas, it’s Amelia,” she said, her voice clear and sure. “Tell Newport I’ll be there. We’ll all be there.” She could hear the smile in his voice, a sound of deep, professional satisfaction and personal warmth. “I was hoping you’d say that, Reverend,” he said. “I’ll make the calls. Get ready to make a joyful noise.”

The following Sunday felt different. A sense of shared purpose, a new chapter in their collective story, hummed in the air. Amelia, standing at the pulpit, looked out at her congregation, at the familiar faces that were the bedrock of her life. She told them about Newport, framing it not as a concert or a performance, but as a pilgrimage. She spoke of Mahalia Jackson and the legacy of that Sunday morning stage. “They have invited us,” she said, making sure to use the plural, “to share the music of our faith, the very hymns and spirituals that have sustained this church and our ancestors, on that historic ground. I cannot go as a solo artist. I can only go as your reverend, as a representative of St. Jude’s-in-the-Swamp, carrying our songs with me.” From his usual seat in the third row, Martha Abernathy’s new son-in-law, a young man who had only recently started attending services, gave a single, firm nod of approval. A low murmur of assent rippled through the pews. It was not a standing ovation, but something far more meaningful: a quiet, unanimous consent. They were sending her.

Her phone call with Spoon that evening was a joyous cacophony. Before she could even get the words out, he interrupted her. “Silas already called! Newport! Can you believe it, Reverend? The big stage! Russell just about fell off his drum stool, and Clay said he needs to buy a new suit jacket. We’re putting the band back together!” His laughter was a warm, rumbling sound that traveled across the phone lines, erasing the miles between Florida and Tennessee. “We’re gonna have us some church up there, you hear me? We’re gonna take ‘em right to the river.” The easy camaraderie, the shared, unadulterated excitement for the music itself, washed away any lingering trace of Amelia’s anxiety. This wasn’t a solo journey. She would be standing on that stage surrounded by her band, her friends, and supported by the silent, powerful prayers of her congregation a thousand miles away. The wayfaring stranger was still traveling, but she was no longer alone.The journey to Rhode Island felt like a reverse pilgrimage, a trip away from the familiar heat of the South toward the crisp, historical air of New England. This time, there was no black SUV waiting at the curb, no chirpy talent liaison managing her every move. Amelia flew commercial, a simple traveler with a suitcase and a guitar case, her Book of Common Prayer tucked in her carry-on next to the thermos of Earl Grey that Beatrice had insisted upon. The flight was not an acceleration away from a known self, but a calm, steady journey toward a specific purpose. As the plane descended over the sparkling expanse of Narragansett Bay, the landscape dotted with sailboats and the elegant spires of colonial churches, she felt not a sense of dislocation, but of arrival. She was a wayfaring stranger, traveling to a place she had only ever read about, a ground made holy by the history of the music she carried within her.

Newport was a town out of time, its narrow streets lined with perfectly preserved colonial homes and grand, Gilded Age mansions that stood as silent monuments to a different kind of American royalty. The air smelled of salt and low tide, a clean, briny scent that was a world away from the jasmine and damp earth of Gainesville. The light was different here, too; a clear, almost crystalline light that seemed to sharpen the edges of the world, making the blue of the bay and the green of the manicured lawns feel preternaturally vivid. Silas had arranged for her to stay in a small, historic inn a few blocks from the harbor, a place with creaking floorboards, four-poster beds, and a quiet, dignified charm. It was the antithesis of the sterile, minimalist cube of the Mondrian. It felt like a place with stories, a place that respected the past.

She met the band in the inn’s cozy, wood-paneled lobby. They had driven up from their respective homes, their reunion a warm, easy affair, full of handshakes that turned into hugs and the comfortable shorthand of musicians who had found a shared groove. Spoon, whose floral-print shirt was a vibrant splash of southern warmth against the staid New England decor, was practically vibrating with excitement. Clay was his usual self, a pillar of quiet confidence, though his eyes held a spark of deep anticipation. Russell, the young drummer, seemed almost reverent, his gaze drawn to the window as if he could already hear the music from across the water. They were not competitors or colleagues; they were a unit, a small congregation that had traveled from afar, ready to give their testimony.

That afternoon, they took the water taxi across the harbor to Fort Adams State Park, where the festival was already beginning to stir. The sight of the massive, historic fort, its stone walls overlooking the bay, was breathtaking. Spread across the green lawns before it were several stages, webs of scaffolding and sound equipment being meticulously assembled under the summer sun. The air was alive with a symphony of soundchecks: the lonesome cry of a pedal steel from one stage, the intricate fingerpicking of a folk singer from another, the low, steady thrum of an upright bass from a tent nearby. It was not the frantic, insulated chaos of a television studio; it was an open, communal gathering, a convocation of tribes all drawn by the same magnetic pull of authentic music. They found the main stage, a huge, majestic structure with the deep blue of the bay as its backdrop. It was empty now, silent and waiting. Standing before it, Amelia felt the weight of its history, the ghosts of the voices that had soared from its platform. It was not an intimidating feeling, but a humbling one. She was about to become a small part of a very long, very beautiful story.

They spent the next day exploring the festival, which had now blossomed into a vibrant, sprawling village. They wandered from stage to stage, artist passes dangling from their necks, becoming part of the vast, good-natured crowd. They listened to a fiery bluegrass band from Kentucky that had the audience on its feet, and a young, intense singer-songwriter whose lyrics were as sharp and clear as the Newport light. Amelia saw musicians she recognized from the covers of her father’s old records, now older, their faces lined with the maps of their lives, sitting on blankets and listening to younger artists with quiet, appreciative attention. There was no hierarchy here, no velvet rope separating the stars from the audience. Everyone was a fan, a participant in a shared love. No one pointed at Amelia’s collar or whispered about the “singing vicar.” Here, surrounded by the diverse chorus of American folk traditions, her story wasn’t a gimmick; it was just one authentic narrative among many. She felt not like an outsider, but like she had finally found her tribe.

On Saturday evening, as the sun began to set, casting a golden glow over the harbor, the four of them found a quiet spot on the ramparts of the old fort, looking down at the festival below. The main stage was alive with the final headliner of the evening, the sound of electric guitars and a powerful rock anthem echoing across the water. They didn’t talk much, each lost in their own thoughts. Spoon idly tapped out a rhythm on his knees. Clay stared out at the sailboats gliding across the bay. Amelia clutched the cool iron railing, the sea breeze on her face, and thought of her father. She wished he could see this, could feel the palpable joy and respect for the music that filled the air. She imagined him sitting here beside her, a rare, quiet smile on his face, finally at home among people who understood the sacred power of a song. The noise and spectacle of the rock show faded into the background, and in her mind, she could hear a different sound: the spare, haunting chords of a lone guitar and the clear, steady promise of a voice singing about a journey home. Tomorrow, that voice would be hers.Sunday morning rose over Newport with a gentle, pearlescent light, the sun burning off the last remnants of a cool sea fog. The distant clang of a buoy bell replaced the chaotic song of the Gainesville mockingbird, a slow, metronomic heartbeat counting down the hours. Amelia woke not with a jolt of anxiety, but with a deep, settled calm. This day was not an ordeal to be survived, but a service to be rendered. She bypassed her usual routine of vocal warm-ups, choosing instead to sit by the open window of her room at the inn, her well-worn Book of Common Prayer open on her lap. She read the collect for the day, the ancient words a quiet anchor in the morning’s stillness: “O God, you have taught us to keep all your commandments by loving you and our neighbor: Grant us the grace of your Holy Spirit, that we may be devoted to you with our whole heart, and united to one another with pure affection…” It was a prayer not for a flawless performance, but for a true connection.

The backstage area of the festival, even on its final day, was a world away from the hermetic, high-strung panic of the television studio. Here, the atmosphere was one of relaxed, communal purpose. Musicians in various states of dress sat on overturned equipment cases, drinking coffee and quietly tuning their instruments. The air smelled of salt, strong coffee, and the faint, sweet scent of trampled grass. Amelia found her band gathered in the shade of a large tent designated for the main stage artists. There was no nervous pacing, no last-minute pep talks. Spoon was meticulously polishing the wooden casing of his portable organ’s keyboard, a quiet act of respect for his instrument. Clay, leaning against a tent pole, was slowly rosining his bow, his movements as meditative as a monk’s. Russell sat on a bale of hay, his drumsticks resting loosely in his hands, his gaze fixed on the endless blue of the bay. They greeted her with quiet nods, a shared understanding passing between them that needed no words. They were ready.

A young woman with a kind smile and a sun-faded festival t-shirt appeared a few minutes before eleven, a stark contrast to the headset-wearing, tablet-wielding runners of Los Angeles. “Reverend Cartwright? They’re ready for you,” she said softly. The walk from the tent to the side of the stage was a short journey through a symphony of quiet anticipation. The announcer’s voice, warm and resonant, boomed out over the crowd. “Good morning, and welcome to the final day of the Newport Folk Festival. For decades, this Sunday morning slot has been a time for reflection, for praise, and for some of the most powerful music ever to grace this stage. It is a tradition sanctified by the great Mahalia Jackson. And today, to carry on that tradition, please welcome a remarkable new voice, the Reverend Amelia Cartwright and her band!” The mention of Mahalia’s name sent a shiver through Amelia, a jolt of historical weight and profound responsibility. She took a deep breath, walked out from the wings, and stepped into the light.

The view from the stage was staggering. It was not a dark, anonymous void, but a vast, sun-drenched landscape of humanity. Thousands of people were spread across the green lawn, a sea of faces turned toward the stage. There were families on blankets, grizzled folk music veterans in lawn chairs who had likely been here for Mahalia herself, and young, tattooed music lovers sitting cross-legged on the grass. And behind them all, the great, glittering expanse of Narragansett Bay, dotted with white sailboats that bobbed gently on the tide. It was a real place, filled with real people, on a real Sunday morning. Amelia took her place at the microphone, looking out at the living, breathing congregation before her. She gave them a warm, genuine smile. “Good morning,” she said, her voice clear and steady, carrying out over the vast crowd. “It is a true and humbling honor to be here with you all. I can’t think of a better way to spend a Sunday morning. So let’s have a little church together, shall we?”

Without another word, she began to strum the opening chords of “Will the Circle Be Unbroken?” on her acoustic guitar. The band joined in behind her, Spoon’s organ swelling like a church processional, Clay’s bass providing a heartbeat, and Russell’s drums a gentle, shuffling train rhythm. When she began to sing the first verse, her voice was not a performance but an invitation. It was a call to community, a question posed to every person sitting on that lawn. By the time she reached the first chorus, a beautiful thing began to happen. A low murmur in the crowd grew as people began to sing along, their voices, tentative at first, then growing in strength, joining hers. “There’s a better home a-waitin’, in the sky, Lord, in the sky.” The sound of thousands of voices rising together was more powerful than any applause. She was not singing to them; they were all singing together, a makeshift choir on the shores of the bay.

From that opening declaration of community, she seamlessly transitioned into the fiery heart of the set. “I feel a little rain comin’ on,” she declared, her voice taking on a new power as the band launched into the driving, sanctified rhythm of “Didn’t It Rain.” This was the full force of the Nashville sessions unleashed, the sound of a band in perfect, joyful communion. Amelia’s voice soared, filled with the grit and glory she had found in that woody studio. Spoon stood up from his bench, his hands flying across the organ keys in a solo that was pure, unadulterated testimony, a sermon in motion. The crowd, already warmed by the opening hymn, rose to its feet, a wave of clapping hands and swaying bodies sweeping across the lawn. This was not a polite, seated folk concert. It was a revival, a full-throated celebration of a spirit that refused to be dampened by any storm.

After the song’s thunderous conclusion, she allowed a moment of quiet to settle, letting the crowd catch its breath. She spoke again, her voice softer now, more intimate. “That music, the blues and the spirituals, it was born out of trouble,” she said, her gaze sweeping across the sea of faces. “It comes from the dark places, from the sorrow and the struggle. But it never stays there. It always, always looks toward the morning. It’s a testament to the belief that no matter how long the night, a change is gonna come.” The familiar phrase, now imbued with the weight of her entire journey, resonated with a new power. It was no longer just a song title; it was the core of her creed.

She took a sip of water, and then nodded to the band. “This last one,” she said, her voice dropping to a near-whisper, “this is for the great woman who made this ground so holy. This is for Mahalia.” The band began the introduction to “Move On Up a Little Higher,” the arrangement spare and majestic. Amelia closed her eyes and sang. The song was a story, a vision of the journey from the trials of this world to the glory of the next, and her voice became a vessel for that narrative. It climbed, note by note, verse by verse, a ladder of sound ascending toward the clear blue sky. It was no longer a performance. It was an offering, a prayer of gratitude for the journey, for the music, for the chance to stand on this stage and add her own small voice to its mighty chorus.

She held the final, soaring note, a sound of pure, transcendent hope, letting it hang in the salt air until it dissolved into the vastness of the sky and the bay. And then, there was a profound and absolute silence. The entire festival, it seemed, held its breath. It was a stillness more powerful than any standing ovation, a shared moment of grace and awe. Finally, the spell broke, and a sound rose from the crowd—not the explosive roar of a television studio, but a deep, rolling wave of applause, a sound of profound, heartfelt gratitude that seemed to rise from the very earth itself. Amelia opened her eyes, tears glistening on her cheeks, and bowed her head. She looked over at Spoon, Clay, and Russell, and in their eyes, she saw the same exhausted, exultant joy she felt in her own heart. They had come to this place, and they had done what they were sent to do. They had brought the church to the people, and it was good.

Backstage, in the shade of the tent, the air was thick with a feeling of joyful release. Silas was the first to greet them, his usual professional reserve melted away, his face alight with a rare, unguarded smile. He didn’t offer congratulations or critique. He simply handed Amelia a bottle of cold water and said, “Thank you, Reverend. That was a gift.” Spoon enveloped her in a bone-crushing hug, lifting her off her feet. “We had us some church!” he roared, his voice thick with emotion. Clay and Russell stood by, their faces beaming, a silent, powerful camaraderie radiating from them. The journey that had started with a hesitant phone call in a quiet church office had culminated in this shared moment of grace. Amelia leaned against a tent pole, the sounds of the festival starting up again on a distant stage, and took a long drink of water. She looked out through a gap in the tent at the slice of blue bay, the sailboats gliding past, the sun high in the sky. The wayfaring stranger had traveled far, through worlds of spectacle and sorrow, but standing here, on this hallowed ground, surrounded by her friends, she felt, finally and completely, at home.

The old cypress knees of St. Jude’s-in-the-Swamp had heard it all. They’d soaked in the somber dirges of a hundred funerals and the reedy triumph of a thousand Easter hymns. But they had never heard anything quite like the sound Reverend Amelia Cartwright was making on this particular Tuesday afternoon. It started as a low, mournful hum, a note that seemed to rise from the very peat and loam of the Gainesville earth, then it caught, climbed, and unfurled into a ribbon of pure, gut-punching soul. It wasn't a hymn, not unless Aretha Franklin had secretly been rewriting the hymnal. It was a lament, a plea, and a defiant roar all at once, bouncing off the vaulted ceiling and making the dust motes dance in the slanted columns of afternoon light.

Amelia, her black clerical shirt sticking to her back in the humid air, held the final note until her lungs burned, her eyes shut tight. In that moment, she wasn't the Reverend Cartwright, the one who counseled grieving widows and argued about the font for the church newsletter. She was just Amy, a woman with a voice too big for her body, a sound forged in a crucible of gospel choirs and her daddy’s scratchy blues records. The silence that followed was heavier, more profound, than the note itself. It was a silence filled with the ghost of the song. She opened her eyes, a giddy smile playing on her lips. The empty pews were her most honest audience. They never judged.

The spell was broken by the shrill, profane shriek of the telephone from her office, a sound as jarring in the sanctuary's peace as a firecracker in a library. Amelia sighed, the last of the melody evaporating from the air. Reality, in the form of church business, always called. She padded across the cool flagstones, her sensible shoes making soft, apologetic sounds. "St. Jude's, Reverend Cartwright speaking," she said, her voice dropping back into its usual gentle, pastoral cadence.

"Amy! It's Chad! From the show!" The voice on the other end was a thousand miles away from Gainesville, all L.A. sunshine, caffeine, and naked ambition. Chad, the junior producer for ‘America’s Next Voice,’ a man who spoke in exclamation points.

Amelia’s heart did a frantic little tap-dance against her ribs. "Chad. Hello. Any news?" She tried to keep her voice even, to sound like a woman who had more important things to think about than a televised singing competition. It was a terrible piece of acting.

"News? Honey, I have THE news! You're in! The final! The network loved the semi-final tape. The whole 'singing vicar' angle is gold, pure gold! They're flying you out Sunday. First-class. We’re putting you up at the Mondrian. Is that insane or is that insane?!"

Amelia sank into her creaky office chair, the receiver suddenly slippery in her palm. The Mondrian. First-class. The Final. The words were alien, shimmering things, landing in her small, cluttered office with its smell of old paper and lemon polish. She looked at the wall, at the framed photo of her ordination, the bishop looking stern, herself looking young and terrified. What would he think of the Mondrian? "I… I don't know what to say, Chad."

"Say you'll be there! Say you're ready to blow the roof off the place! We've got Marco the Crooner, that little pop-punk kid Skyler, and you. The holy trinity of vocal warfare! It's gonna be epic, Amy. Epic!"

Holy trinity. Amelia almost choked on a laugh. Oh, if only he knew. "I'll be there, Chad," she managed, a wave of giddiness making her feel lightheaded. "I'll be there."

When she hung up, the silence of the office rushed back in, but it was a different kind of silence now. It was electric. She stood up, walked back into the sanctuary, and stood in the very spot where she’d been singing. The light was fading, turning the stained-glass depiction of St. Jude, patron saint of lost causes, into a jewel-toned mosaic. A lost cause. That’s what her father had called her desire to be a singer. 'You have the voice of an angel, Amy-girl,' he'd said, his own voice rough with whiskey and regret, 'but this world chews up angels and spits 'em out.' And so she’d chosen a different flock, a different kind of service. Yet, here it was. The lost cause, found. She threw her head back and let out a laugh that was pure, unadulterated joy, a sound that sent the pigeons roosting in the belfry scattering into the purple dusk. The Reverend Amelia Cartwright was going to Hollywood.

Her church secretary, Beatrice, a woman whose sharp angles and sharper tongue concealed a heart of surprising softness, was less effusive. When Amelia told her the news the next morning over lukewarm coffee and a plate of day-old muffins, Beatrice simply raised a perfectly sculpted eyebrow. "Los Angeles," she said, as if tasting a word she found foul. "They're not Episcopalian out there, you know. They worship gluten-free toast and their own reflections."

"Bea, be nice. This is a huge opportunity," Amelia said, still buzzing with an energy that felt foreign and wonderful.

"It's an opportunity to be humiliated on national television by a man named 'Marco the Crooner,' who I'm sure is as oily as a mechanic's rag," Beatrice retorted, tapping a perfectly manicured nail on the stack of mail. "And what about the parish? Who's going to officiate the bake sale on Saturday? Who's going to listen to Mrs. Higgins's weekly complaint about the length of the new hymn?"

"You are," Amelia said with a grin. "And you'll be brilliant. It’s just for a week or so. Think of it as a mission trip. I'm going into the wilderness to spread the good word."

"The good word of Leiber and Stoller, perhaps," Beatrice sniffed, but a tiny smile betrayed her. "Alright. Go on. Go be a star. But if you come back with a vocal fry and a chihuahua in your purse, I'm resigning." She paused, her expression softening for a fraction of a second. "Just… be careful, Amy. That world isn't like this one. It’s all teeth."

The warning echoed in Amelia’s mind a few days later as she stood in her bedroom, a black clerical robe laid out on the bed next to a shimmering, peacock-blue dress she’d bought on a whim. The two garments looked like emissaries from warring nations. One represented duty, solemnity, peace. The other, hope, audacity, and a terrifying, thrilling vanity. She picked up her collar, the stiff white plastic cool against her fingers. She had worn it for so long it felt like a part of her skin. Could she be Amy the singer without betraying Amelia the Reverend? The congregation’s reaction had been a mixed bag of Southern charm and suspicion. Most were thrilled, planning viewing parties and making signs. But she’d overheard old Mr. Abernathy muttering to his wife about "worldly temptations" and "making a spectacle of the cloth."

She was making a spectacle, wasn't she? A spectacle of joy. A spectacle of a gift she had tried to keep tucked away, using it only for the glory of God in the most literal sense. But the gift didn't want to be tucked away. It wanted the stage lights. It wanted to reach people who would never set foot in St. Jude’s-in-the-Swamp. She folded the robe carefully and placed it in her suitcase. Then, she picked up the blue dress. The sequins felt like armor. She held it up to herself in the mirror, and for a moment, she saw a stranger looking back. A woman on the precipice of a different life, her eyes wide with a holy and profane terror. The plane ticket was on her dresser. Los Angeles was waiting. St. Jude, patron of lost causes, was either smiling down on her or shaking his head in dismay. Amelia couldn't decide which. And for the first time in a long time, she found she didn't much care. She was flying.

The small Gainesville airport felt like an extension of her own parish. A handful of congregants had turned up for a semi-official send-off, armed with Tupperware containers of pimento cheese sandwiches and a handmade banner that read "SING FOR THE LORD AND GAINESVILLE, AMELIA!" Mrs. Higgins pressed a Ziploc bag of ginger snaps into her hand, "For your nerves, dear," while Beatrice stood by, arms crossed, looking as if she were supervising a particularly risky hostage exchange. She adjusted Amelia’s collar, which Amelia had decided to wear as a sort of shield. “Remember,” Beatrice whispered, her voice a low conspiracy, “Hydrate. Don’t sign anything without reading it thrice. And for heaven’s sake, don’t let them talk you into a spray tan.” The advice was so practical, so Beatrice, that Amelia hugged her fiercely, smelling her familiar scent of Earl Grey tea and righteous indignation. It was the smell of home.

First class was less a section of a plane and more a different dimension. The seat was a plush, cream-colored pod that looked more comfortable than her couch back home. A flight attendant with a smile as bright and flawless as a strip of porcelain veneers offered her champagne before they’d even left the ground. Amelia, flustered, asked for a ginger ale instead. She watched her small town shrink below her, the familiar grid of streets and the green sprawl of Paynes Prairie Preserve giving way to a patchwork of clouds. She pulled out her well-worn Book of Common Prayer, its pages soft as cloth, intending to read the evening service. But her eyes kept straying to the window, to the impossibly blue sky stretching out towards a future she couldn't begin to imagine. The ancient words of the psalter felt distant, their rhythm competing with the thrum of the jet engines and the frantic, syncopated beat of her own heart. She wasn't just flying west; she felt like she was accelerating away from a fixed point, a known self, at a thousand miles an hour.

The sensory assault began the moment she stepped out of the hermetically sealed environment of LAX. The air didn't wrap around you with a damp embrace like it did in Florida; it was a dry, gasoline-tinged heat that felt like standing too close to a furnace. The light was different, too—a relentless, white glare that bleached the color from the sky and seemed to demand sunglasses as a matter of self-preservation. A young woman who looked no older than twenty, holding a tablet with ‘AMY CARTWRIGHT’ glowing on it in futuristic script, intercepted her. "Amy! Hi! I'm Paisley, your talent liaison! Welcome to L.A.! Traffic was a beast, but you are going to LOVE the hotel. We are all, like, *so* psyched to have you." Paisley spoke in a breathless rush, as if she were perpetually two minutes late for the most important event of her life. She led Amelia to a black SUV so polished it reflected the airport's chaotic ballet of arrivals and departures with unnerving clarity.

The drive to West Hollywood was a dizzying montage of the foreign and the familiar. Palm trees lined the freeways, but they were taller, skinnier, and sadder-looking than the ones back home. Billboards the size of houses loomed over them, advertising TV shows and impossibly beautiful people selling impossibly expensive watches. Paisley kept up a constant, chirpy monologue about vocal coaches, wardrobe fittings, and press junkets, the words washing over Amelia like a foreign language she only half-understood. She stared out the window at the endless stream of cars, the sun-drenched storefronts with names like "Go Get Em Tiger" and "Gracias Madre," and felt a profound, unnerving sense of dislocation. This wasn't the wilderness Beatrice had spoken of; it was a different planet, one that operated on its own strange physics and followed its own inscrutable commandments.

The Mondrian hotel rose up from the Sunset Strip like a giant, minimalist white cube, devoid of the ornamentation and history Amelia found comforting. The lobby was a stage set for a play she hadn't been given the script for. Impossibly long-legged women in tiny dresses navigated the space on stiletto heels, while men with carefully curated stubble and expensive-looking t-shirts conducted hushed, important-sounding conversations on their phones. The air smelled of white lilies and money. As Paisley checked her in, Amelia stood by her worn suitcase, feeling conspicuous in her simple black slacks and clerical shirt. She felt like a crow that had accidentally flown into a flock of exotic birds. When the receptionist handed her a key card, a sleek piece of plastic with no discernible teeth, she clutched it like a talisman. This, she thought, was the key to the kingdom. She just wasn't sure if she wanted to go inside.

Her room was a study in white. The walls, the enormous bed with its mountain of pillows, the sleek, low-slung furniture—it was all a pristine, almost clinical white, punctuated only by a single, vibrant blue art piece on the wall that looked like a controlled explosion of paint. A floor-to-ceiling window made up the entire far wall, offering a breathtaking, terrifying vista of Los Angeles spread out below like a carpet of glittering jewels. The sounds of the city, a distant chorus of sirens and traffic, were completely sealed out, creating a silent, sterile bubble high above the chaos of the Sunset Strip. Amelia placed her scuffed suitcase on a luggage rack that looked like a museum sculpture and felt an acute sense of being an imposter, a drab sparrow in a minimalist cage built for birds of paradise.

Unpacking felt like an act of quiet rebellion, of claiming a tiny corner of this alien territory as her own. She placed her Book of Common Prayer on the glass nightstand, its worn leather cover a stark contrast to the glossy surface. Next to it, she set a small, silver-framed photo of her parents, smiling on a fishing boat in the Cedar Key flats. She hung her simple dresses in the cavernous, illuminated closet, where they looked meager and plain. When she pulled out the black clerical robe and the peacock-blue dress, the dilemma she'd faced in her bedroom returned with a new, sharper urgency. Here, in this room with a view of the Hollywood Hills, the two garments seemed less like warring emissaries and more like costumes for two entirely different plays. One was a life of service she knew and understood; the other was a glittering improvisation into the unknown.

Paisley called an hour later, her voice crackling with manufactured urgency. "Amy! Hope you're settling in! We're doing a super low-key welcome dinner for you, Marco, and Skyler up at the Skybar. In thirty! It’s just to, you know, vibe and connect before the madness begins. See you there!" Before Amelia could ask what one wore to "vibe and connect," the line went dead. She looked from her collar to the sequined dress. The choice felt too binary, too absolute. In the end, she compromised, choosing a simple black dress that could have been at home at a church potluck, but she left the collar in its box. It felt both too aggressive and too vulnerable for a rooftop bar. She felt stripped of her armor, armed only with Mrs. Higgins's ginger snaps, which she'd put in her purse for courage.

The Skybar was an open-air pavilion surrounding a pool that glowed with an ethereal blue light. The air was thick with perfume and the low throb of electronic music. Everywhere she looked, beautiful people lounged on white couches, holding drinks and laughing with a practiced, camera-ready ease. Chad spotted her immediately and bounded over, a human exclamation point in a linen blazer. "Amy! There she is! Our soulful songbird! Come, meet the competition." He steered her toward a cabana where two figures were silhouetted against the glittering city lights. "Marco, Skyler, this is Amelia!"

Marco the Crooner unfolded himself from the couch with the fluid grace of a panther. He was even more handsome than his publicity photos suggested, with dark, soulful eyes, a chin that could cut glass, and a smile that seemed to have its own dedicated lighting. He was, as Beatrice had predicted, breathtakingly smooth. He took Amelia’s hand, his grip warm and firm. "Reverend," he said, his voice a low, velvety murmur. "An honor. I saw your semi-final performance. That last note gave me chills. You're the real deal." He made it sound like a compliment, but it felt like a sizing-up, a professional assessment from a seasoned opponent.

The other finalist, Skyler, didn't get up. They remained slouched in the corner of the couch, a riot of pink hair, black eyeliner, and ripped denim, their face illuminated by the glow of their phone. They looked up, offered a distracted, "Hey," and immediately looked back down at their screen. They couldn’t have been older than twenty, radiating a carefully constructed aura of disinterest that was, in its own way, as much a performance as Marco's effortless charm. Amelia suddenly felt a hundred years old. Chad clapped his hands together. "The holy trinity! The Soul, the Swoon, and the Scream! This is ratings gold, people! Gold!" The phrase, which had seemed absurdly funny in her quiet office, felt crass and reductive here, stripping them of their humanity and turning them into marketable archetypes. She was no longer Amelia Cartwright; she was 'The Soul.'

Amelia took a seat on the edge of the couch, clutching her purse on her lap. Marco, ever the gentleman, flagged down a waiter and ordered a bottle of champagne, "To celebrate the three of us." When the waiter came to her, Amelia, feeling the unfamiliarity of it all like a physical weight, simply ordered a glass of water. Marco raised an eyebrow almost imperceptibly. "Keeping a clear head for the battle ahead, Reverend? Smart." He smiled that dazzling smile again, but this time Amelia saw it for what it was: a perfectly polished weapon. Beatrice had been right. This world was all teeth. And they were just getting started.

The bubbles rose in Marco’s flute like a tiny, effervescent applause. He took a delicate sip, his dark eyes fixed on Amelia over the rim of the glass. "It's a brave move, I'll give you that," he continued, his voice dropping into a conspiratorial tone. "The whole reverend thing. A gimmick, sure, but a brilliant one. The network must be ecstatic. It's a narrative people can get behind. The spirit versus the flesh, or whatever." He gestured vaguely at the Hollywood scene around them. "People eat that stuff up. It sets you apart."

The word "gimmick" landed like a stone in the pit of her stomach. He had taken her life's work, her calling, the very core of her identity, and reduced it to a marketing strategy. A part of her wanted to recoil, to explain the years of seminary, the quiet moments holding the hands of the dying, the profound joy of baptizing a newborn. But she saw the trap in his words. To get defensive was to lose. Instead, she offered him a small, placid smile, the kind she usually reserved for particularly trying parish council meetings. "I suppose you could see it that way," she said, her voice even and calm. "But my clerical collar is no more a gimmick than your charm is, Marco. We all wear the uniform that gets us through the day."

A sharp, unexpected snort of laughter came from the corner of the couch. Skyler finally looked up from their phone, a smirk playing on their lips, heavily outlined in black. "Damn," they said, their voice a surprisingly low, gravelly alto. "She got you there, pretty boy." They shoved their phone into a pocket of their ripped jeans and leaned forward, directing their attention to Amelia for the first time. "I saw your tape. That version of 'I Put a Spell on You' was sick. Like, actually good. Not that churchy crap I was expecting." The compliment was wrapped in so much youthful cynicism it was almost unrecognizable, but it was genuine. In that moment, Skyler wasn't "the Scream," the punk caricature; they were just a kid who liked music.

Marco, for the first time, looked momentarily flustered. He recovered with a practiced laugh, raising his hands in mock surrender. "Alright, alright, I'm outnumbered. My apologies, Reverend. It seems my charm, as you call it, needs a tune-up." He winked at Amelia, a slick attempt to reclaim control, but the dynamic in the cabana had subtly shifted. An invisible thread of connection, however thin, had been strung between the reverend and the punk kid, leaving the crooner on the outside. Chad, ever the producer, looked thrilled by the flicker of drama. "See! This is what I'm talking about! Fire and ice! You guys are going to be incredible on camera together."

Paisley, the talent liaison, chose that moment to reappear, tablet in hand, her expression one of cheerful, organized panic. "Okay, team! First-day logistics!" she chirped, and the brief moment of human connection evaporated. "We have a 6 a.m. call time tomorrow. That's a car waiting for you in the lobby. 6 a.m., people, not 6:01. We go straight to the studio for vocal warm-ups with Debra, she's a legend, she works with literally everyone. Then it's two hours of wardrobe and styling, followed by your first round of EPK interviews." She took a breath. "After lunch, Marco, you have a choreography session for your number. Skyler, you're with the band to work through your arrangement. And Amy," she said, her eyes finding Amelia's, "we have you scheduled for a session on stage presence and media training. Just to get you comfortable with the scale of the show. Any questions?"

Amelia's mind reeled. The schedule was a relentless assault, a battle plan for an invasion she hadn't yet agreed to fight. Media training? Stage presence? It sounded like they wanted to sand down her edges, to remold her into a shape that would fit a television screen. She felt a surge of longing for the slow, familiar pace of her life in Gainesville, for the quiet mornings spent writing a sermon, the biggest logistical challenge being a faulty printer. She simply shook her head, the word "no" catching in her throat. The machine was in motion now, and she was just a cog, expected to turn when and how she was told.

Later, back in the silent, white expanse of her room, Amelia stood at the floor-to-ceiling window, the city lights below a vast, indifferent galaxy. The initial excitement that had carried her from Florida had been ground down by the realities of the evening, replaced by a heavy, anxious weariness. The Skybar, with its casual cruelties and calculated performances, had shown her the truth of Beatrice’s words. It was a world of teeth, and they were all so sharp. She saw her reflection faintly in the glass, a solitary figure in a plain black dress, looking small and out of place against the sprawling backdrop of the city. She looked tired. She looked lost.

Turning away from the view, her eyes fell on the worn leather of her Book of Common Prayer on the nightstand. It was a piece of home, an artifact from a truer world. She picked it up, the familiar weight of it a comfort in her hand. Sinking onto the edge of the enormous, sterile bed, she let the book fall open to the Compline, the final prayers for the end of the day. She began to read the ancient words aloud, her voice a quiet murmur in the stillness of the room. "Keep watch, dear Lord, with those who work, or watch, or weep this night, and give your angels charge over those who sleep." The cadence of the prayer was a balm, a rhythm that was older and deeper than the synthetic beat of the music at the bar. The prayer was not a performance. It asked for nothing but peace. It promised nothing but presence. As she spoke the words into the empty, luxurious space, Amelia felt a small, crucial part of herself click back into place. The singer was in Hollywood, yes. But the Reverend was here, too. And she would need her.

The insistent, digital chirping of the hotel alarm at 5:30 a.m. felt like a personal affront. For a moment, disoriented in the pre-dawn gloom of the white room, Amelia thought it was a fire alarm. Then reality crashed in, cold and immediate. 6 a.m. call time. She swung her legs out of the enormous bed, the plush carpet a small, surprising comfort under her feet. The city outside was a muted tapestry of grey and distant, sleeping lights, a far cry from the glittering spectacle of the previous night. She felt the dull throb of sleep deprivation behind her eyes, a familiar sensation from late-night hospital vigils, but this felt different, tinged not with pastoral duty but with a secular, high-stakes anxiety.

In the stark white bathroom, under lights so bright they felt like an interrogation, she looked at her reflection. She looked like a woman who had been flown across a continent and dropped into a life that was not her own. She thought of Marco’s word: gimmick. Today, she would be tested. Today, they would try to shape her. Reaching for her bag, she pulled out the stiff white rectangle of her collar. Her fingers, practiced and sure, fastened it around her neck. It felt less like armor this morning and more like an anchor, a solid, tangible piece of her identity in a world that felt fluid and false. She chose a simple black shirt and black pants, the closest thing she had to a uniform. If they were going to see her as the singing vicar, they were going to see the whole vicar.

Down in the lobby, the atmosphere of curated cool had been replaced by a hushed, purposeful silence. A different black SUV was waiting, purring expectantly at the curb. The driver, a large man with a kind face who introduced himself as Sal, simply nodded at her collar. "Morning, Reverend," he said, his voice a warm, welcome rumble. The drive through the waking city was surreal. The famous streets were nearly empty, populated only by delivery trucks, street sweepers, and the solitary figures of early-morning runners. Sal navigated the freeways with an unspoken expertise, the city unfolding around them in shades of orange and pink as the sun began to rise behind the hazy eastern mountains. He didn't speak, and Amelia was grateful for the silence. It gave her a moment to breathe, to murmur a quick, silent prayer for the day ahead, a simple appeal for grace under pressure.

The studio lot was not in Hollywood but in Burbank, a sprawling, functional city-within-a-city of beige soundstages that looked like colossal packing crates. After passing through a security gate where Sal flashed a pass, they pulled up to a building marked ‘Stage 4’. The moment the door opened, the carefully constructed peace of the morning was shattered. The inside was a hive of frantic, focused activity. People with headsets and clipboards strode purposefully through a labyrinth of cables and lighting equipment, their voices a low, urgent hum. The air smelled strongly of coffee, sawdust, and something faintly electrical. A young man with a headset immediately detached himself from a group and hurried toward her. "Amelia! Great, you're here! I'm Kevin. Right this way, Debra's waiting."

He led her not to a glamorous dressing room, but to a small, soundproofed studio containing little more than a grand piano and a wall of mirrors. A woman with a cascade of silver hair pulled back in a severe bun sat at the keyboard, her back ramrod straight. She didn't turn as they entered. "Leave us, Kevin," she said, her voice possessing a calm authority that cut through the surrounding chaos. As the door clicked shut, she turned on the piano bench. Her face was a map of fine lines, and her eyes, a piercing blue, seemed to take in everything about Amelia in a single, unblinking assessment. This was Debra, the legend. "Reverend Amelia Cartwright," she said. It wasn't a question. "I've heard a lot about you. Forget all of it. I don't care about your story, I care about your larynx. Sit."

Amelia sat on a stool near the piano, feeling like a student called to the principal's office. Debra's fingers danced over the keys, playing a simple, ascending scale. "Sing," she commanded. Amelia opened her mouth and followed the notes, her voice still thick with sleep. Debra stopped her after a few bars. "No. Not from the church. Not from the television. From here." She tapped her own sternum with two fingers. "That sound you made on the tape, the one where you almost broke the microphone? That came from your gut. It was trained in a gospel choir, wasn't it? And you listened to a lot of blues growing up." Amelia, startled by the accuracy, could only nod. "I thought so," Debra said, a flicker of a smile touching her lips. "It's a wonderful, dangerous instrument you have. You've learned to control it for hymns, to fill a sanctuary without hurting yourself. But you haven't really let it go in a long time. You're afraid of it. We're not going to be afraid of it in here." For the next hour, there was no talk of television, competition, or narratives. There was only breath, scales, resonance, and power. Debra pushed her, challenged her, and for the first time since arriving, Amelia felt a spark of genuine joy. It was the joy of the work, the craft.

The peace of the vocal session was promptly obliterated by the wardrobe department. It was a vast room, a riot of color and texture, with rolling racks of clothes that seemed to stretch on for miles. A man named Antoine, who had a silver streak in his hair and an expression of deep, artistic suffering, circled Amelia like a sculptor assessing a block of marble. "No, no, no," he muttered, waving a dismissive hand at her clerical attire. "It's too on the nose. Too severe. We need to soften it. Give you a halo, not a yoke." He and his assistants began pulling garments from the racks—dresses in flowing cream-colored fabrics, silk blouses in jewel tones, things with ethereal-looking capes. "The network wants 'angelic,'" Antoine explained, "but with a hint of soul. Think Florence Welch officiating a very chic wedding."

He paused, his eyes narrowing on her neck. "And the collar, darling. It will have to go for the performance. It reads terribly on camera. Flattens the light, creates shadows. We can give you a beautiful necklace, something that catches the light." This was it. The first real push. Amelia stood very still amidst the whirlwind of silk and sequins. "The collar stays," she said, her voice quiet but firm. Antoine sighed dramatically. "But it's a costume choice, and I am the costume designer." Amelia met his gaze, her expression unwavering. "With respect, Antoine, it's not a costume. It's my life. It's who I am. If you want Amelia Cartwright, you get her. All of her." There was a tense silence, the assistants freezing with armfuls of fabric. Antoine stared at her, then a slow smile spread across his face. "Alright, Reverend," he said, with a newfound respect in his tone. "Challenge accepted. If the collar stays, then we make the collar fashion." The battle was small, but Amelia felt a surge of victory. It wasn't just about a piece of plastic; it was about not letting them edit her soul for prime time.

The victory with Antoine left Amelia feeling buoyed, as if she’d successfully defended a small but crucial piece of sovereign territory. That feeling, however, began to dissipate as Kevin, the headset-wearing guide, led her through another series of identical corridors to a room designated for media training. The space was set up like a miniature television studio, with several cameras pointed at a small, brightly lit stage where three chairs were arranged in a gentle arc. Marco was already there, lounging in one of the chairs and chatting easily with a woman who held a tablet and radiated an aura of terrifying competence. Skyler was conspicuously absent.

"Amy, perfect! This is Jocelyn," Chad said, appearing from the shadows of the control booth with his signature explosive energy. "Jocelyn is our artist development guru. She's going to help you all shape your stories for the press. She's the best." Jocelyn gave Amelia a smile that was wide but didn't reach her eyes. She was whip-thin, dressed in sharp-angled black, and looked like she subsisted entirely on espresso and the weaknesses of others. "Reverend. A pleasure. We have so much to work with here. The narrative is fantastic." The word ‘narrative’ again. In this world, it seemed, life wasn't lived, it was curated.

Just then, Skyler ambled in, headphones clamped over their ears, moving with a deliberate slowness that was a clear act of passive resistance. They slumped into the empty chair furthest from Marco, not acknowledging anyone. Jocelyn’s professional smile tightened by a millimeter. "Welcome, Skyler. Glad you could join us. Now, let's begin. The finale isn't just about the final song. It's about the final story. The audience needs to fall in love with you before you even sing a note. Marco, let's start with you. Give me your sixty-second elevator pitch. Who are you?"

Marco leaned forward, his posture a study in relaxed confidence. "Well, Jocelyn," he began, his voice a smooth baritone, "I'm a man who believes in the classics. In a world of digital noise, I want to bring back a little old-school romance, a little Sinatra, a little Dean Martin. I'm singing for my grandfather, who taught me every song I know and always believed I could bring a little more class, a little more love, into the world with my voice." It was polished, heartfelt, and utterly perfect. Jocelyn beamed. "Excellent! See? It's about legacy, romance, tradition. The viewers will love it." She turned her laser-like focus to Skyler. "Skyler? Your turn."

Skyler pulled off their headphones with an audible sigh. "I'm a kid from Phoenix who makes noise. That's it." Jocelyn's smile faltered. "Okay, but let's dig deeper. What's the 'why' behind the noise? Are you raging against the machine? Giving a voice to the voiceless?" Skyler shrugged, their gaze fixed on a scuff on their combat boot. "I don't know. The machine pays for the recording studio, so... And the voiceless can speak for themselves. I just think a lot of stuff sucks, and I like loud guitars." The defiance was so complete, so uncooperative, that it became its own kind of compelling brand. Chad, watching from the wings, scribbled furiously on a notepad, a grin spreading across his face.

Finally, Jocelyn’s gaze fell upon Amelia. "And now, the Reverend. Amy, your story is pure gold. A woman of God, torn between two callings. The sacred and the profane." Amelia felt a familiar prickle of resistance. "I don't see it as a conflict," she said politely. "My faith and my music come from the same place. It's all about connection, about trying to express something that's bigger than we are." Jocelyn's eyes lit up. "Yes! That's good. But we can punch it up. Let's talk about the sacrifice. You gave up a promising career, your one big dream, to serve a higher power. And now, in a twist of fate, that dream has found you again. It’s a story of redemption. Your lost cause, found."

The phrase, her own private thought from the sanctuary, sounded cheap and theatrical on Jocelyn’s lips. It stripped the years of her ministry of their meaning, rendering them a waiting period, a long, sad prelude to the main event. "That's not how it was," Amelia said, her voice quiet but firm in the brightly lit room. "Choosing the church wasn't giving up on a dream. It was answering a different call. A call to be present with people in their joys and their sorrows. That life has a profound meaning for me. This," she gestured to the cameras, the lights, "this is a wonderful, unexpected gift. But it's not a redemption, because my life was never a tragedy."

Jocelyn’s pen froze over her tablet. The air grew thick with a tense silence. Marco watched Amelia with a new, calculating interest. Skyler, for the first time, looked at her with something akin to respect. Amelia felt her heart pounding, the same frantic tap-dance it had performed in her office. She had refused to play the game, refused to reduce her life to a soundbite. Jocelyn held her gaze for a long moment before a slow, reptilian smile returned to her face. "Okay," she said, her voice dangerously smooth. "Okay, Reverend. You don't want to be the redeemed saint. You want to be the righteous one. The immovable object. That's a story, too. A harder one to sell, but we can work with it. We can definitely work with that." The session ended soon after, but Jocelyn’s final words chilled Amelia more than any of her earlier attempts at manipulation. Jocelyn hadn't been defeated. She had simply found a new box to put Amelia in.

The feeling of being neatly categorized and filed away by Jocelyn lingered like a bad taste as Kevin led Amelia from the media training room. He guided her through a dark passage that opened up onto the main stage of the ‘America’s Next Voice’ theater. The sudden vastness of the space made her breath catch. From her couch in Gainesville, the stage had looked vibrant and intimate. Standing in the center of it, under the glare of sterile work lights, it felt cavernous and intimidating. Rows and rows of empty seats climbed up into the darkness, a silent, thousand-eyed beast waiting to be fed. The scale of it was designed to make a person feel small, and for a moment, it succeeded.

A man with frosted blond tips and impossibly white teeth bounded onto the stage from the wings. He wore track pants and a tight-fitting shirt that read "CREATE YOUR MOMENT." "Amelia! Sweetheart! I'm Dex, and I am your creative movement director!" he announced, air-kissing both of her cheeks. "Jocelyn gave me the download. 'Righteous.' 'Immovable.' Honey, I love it. It’s very Joan of Arc. Very dramatic. But we need to translate that strength into movement, so you don't just look like a deer in the klieg lights. What are we singing?" He was a whirlwind of kinetic energy, the polar opposite of Debra's grounded stillness.

"A Change Is Gonna Come," Amelia said, the title feeling more like a prayer than ever. "Sam Cooke." Dex’s eyes lit up. "Ooh, a classic! Power, pain, hope. I love it! Okay, let's hear a little." A technician somewhere in the darkness hit a button, and the simple, soulful instrumental track began to play through the massive sound system. Amelia took a breath, centered herself as Debra had taught her, and began to sing. "I was born by the river, in a little tent…" Her voice, rich and full, filled the empty theater, the notes pure and unadorned. She sang from her gut, her feet planted firmly on the stage, her eyes closed.

"Stop, stop, stop!" Dex called out, waving his hands frantically. The music cut off abruptly. "Darling, that was gorgeous. For radio. But this is television! I'm not feeling the story with my eyes. You’re standing there like you’re waiting for a bus. Where’s the journey? 'Born by the river'—I want to see the river! Give me some flow, some movement." He demonstrated, his arms making languid, wavy motions. "Then, when he sings about 'somebody keep telling me don't hang around'—that's your moment of struggle. You walk to the edge of the stage, you look out at that audience, you make them feel your oppression."

Amelia stared at him, bewildered. "You want me to act out the lyrics? Like a game of charades?" Dex sighed, a pained, theatrical sound. "It’s not charades, sweetheart, it's performance. It’s connecting. When you get to that big line—'It's been a long, a long time coming'—I want you to drop to your knees. Can you imagine? The lights hit you, you're on your knees, your voice is soaring… there won't be a dry eye in America!" The suggestion was so jarringly, comically wrong that Amelia almost laughed. Dropping to her knees on command felt like a parody of prayer, a hollow gesture designed to wring out emotion rather than express it.

"Dex, with all due respect, that's not me," she said, her voice steady. "The power of that song is in its stillness. It's the testimony of a man who has endured, who is standing firm and declaring that change will come. It's not about histrionics. It's about soul." From the shadowy edge of the stage, a slow, deliberate clap echoed through the theater. Skyler emerged from the darkness, holding a bottle of water. They'd evidently been watching the whole exchange. "She's right," Skyler said, their voice flat. "It'd look stupid. Let her just sing the damn song. Her voice is the whole show." Dex shot them a withering glare, but Skyler just shrugged, unimpressed, and leaned against a piece of scaffolding.

An awkward silence descended upon the stage. Amelia felt a small surge of gratitude for the unexpected, and likely unintentional, rescue. Chad’s voice suddenly boomed from the theater’s sound system, disembodied and godlike. "Let's try it Amy's way, Dex. Let's get a camera on her and see how it reads." Defeated, Dex threw his hands up. "Fine! Plant yourself like one of your cypress trees. But don't blame me if the focus groups say you're 'low-energy.'" The music started again. This time, Amelia ignored Dex, ignored the invisible cameras. She looked out into the black void of the empty seats and imagined it was her own congregation. She sang for Mrs. Higgins, for Beatrice, for the ghost of her father. She sang for the lost causes. The notes of "A Change Is Gonna Come" poured out of her, a lament and a defiant roar, just as her song had in the sanctuary. When she held the final note, the silence that followed was heavier, more profound, than any applause. For a moment, no one spoke. Even the disembodied voice of Chad was quiet. In that silence, Amelia knew she had won more than just an argument. She had held her ground.

That evening, exhausted and emotionally frayed, Amelia sat on the edge of her bed and dialed the number for the church office. The phone rang four times before it was picked up with an audible clatter. "St. Jude's, what do you want?" Beatrice’s gruff voice was the most beautiful sound she’d heard all day. "Bea, it's me," Amelia said, a wave of homesickness washing over her. "Oh, it's you," Beatrice said, her tone softening fractionally. "I suppose you haven't been excommunicated for heresy yet. How is Sodom and/or Gomorrah?"

Amelia laughed, a real, genuine laugh that eased some of the tension in her shoulders. "It's a lot, Bea. They want me to fall on my knees on cue and they refer to my entire life as a 'narrative.'" There was a sniff on the other end of the line. "Of course they do. They're heathens. Did you tell them where they could stick their narrative?" "In my own way," Amelia said, smiling. "How are things there? Did Mrs. Higgins complain about the hymn length?" "Naturally," Beatrice reported. "Number 437 was, and I quote, 'unconscionably long and far too jaunty for a Sunday morning.' I told her I would take it under advisement. The bake sale also raised two hundred and twelve dollars, and I have it on good authority that Edna Mae's lemon bars were not from scratch." The sheer, wonderful mundanity of it all was a lifeline. It was a reminder of a world where problems were small and real, where successes were measured in bake sale dollars, not focus group results.

"Just sing the song, Amy," Beatrice said, her voice suddenly serious. "Don't let those people with their white teeth and empty heads get into yours. You just open your mouth and sing the way you do. The rest is just noise." "Thank you, Bea," Amelia whispered, her throat tight. "Now go to bed," Beatrice commanded. "You'll need your strength to smite the Philistines." When she hung up, the white room felt a little less sterile. The conversation had been like a cool drink of water in the desert. She stood up and walked to the closet, pulling out the shimmering, peacock-blue dress. She held it against herself, looking in the mirror. It was still audacious, still terrifying. But after the day she’d had, it looked less like a costume for a stranger and more like a challenge she might actually be ready to meet. The dress wasn't an act of becoming someone else. It was a declaration that Reverend Amelia Cartwright, in all her righteous, immovable, soul-singing glory, had arrived.

The morning of the final arrived not with a thunderclap but with an unnatural stillness. The Los Angeles sky was a pale, hazy wash, the sun a diffuse glow behind a thin layer of marine fog. Amelia woke before her alarm, her body humming with an energy that was part anxiety, part exhilaration. She went to the window, looking down at the silent city, and felt a profound sense of calm settle over her. The battles of the past week—with Jocelyn’s narratives, with Dex’s choreography, with her own internal doubts—had been fought and, in their own small ways, won. Today was not for fighting. Today was for singing. She unzipped her suitcase and laid the peacock-blue dress out on the bed. In the soft morning light, it didn't look like armor anymore. It looked like wings.

The backstage area of Stage 4 had transformed from a frantic hive into a full-blown military operation. The ambient hum had been replaced by the sharp, staccato commands of stage managers and the palpable buzz of a live audience filtering into the theater, their collective energy seeping through the thick walls. In the midst of the chaos, the three finalists were islands of focused tension. Marco, already in a flawlessly tailored tuxedo, was in a quiet corner with Debra, running through barely audible vocal exercises, his face a mask of serene concentration. Skyler, by contrast, was a caged animal, pacing a small circle near the catering table, their pink hair slightly disheveled. The aura of manufactured disinterest had evaporated completely, revealing a terrified young artist face to face with the biggest moment of their life. They weren't sipping a craft beer; they were nervously chugging from a bottle of water, their eyes wide and fixed on some distant point.

Amelia’s dressing room, which had been a sterile white box, was now her sanctuary. Antoine, the costume designer, was there, not as a combatant, but as a conspirator. “I had an epiphany, Reverend,” he declared, holding up the blue dress. “If you must wear the yoke,” he said, gesturing to her collar, “it must be enthroned.” He had made a subtle but brilliant alteration. The simple neckline of the dress had been reshaped, dipping slightly to perfectly frame the clerical collar, its edge trimmed with a single, delicate line of silver thread that caught the light. It wasn't a compromise; it was an integration. It made the collar look not like a relic from another life, but an essential, intentional part of the whole stunning design. As she slipped the dress on, the cool sequins felt like a second skin. She looked at her reflection in the lit mirror—the reverend from Gainesville in a Hollywood gown, her eyes clear, her posture straight. It was not a spectacle. It was a statement.

There was a soft knock on her door. It was Skyler, their knuckles white where they gripped their microphone. "They said five minutes," they mumbled, their voice barely a whisper. They looked at Amelia, the sequined dress, the collar. "You look... legit," they said, the highest form of compliment in their lexicon. "I think I'm gonna throw up." The punk bravado was completely gone, replaced by the raw fear of a kid who was in over their head. Amelia felt her pastoral instincts kick in, gentle and automatic. "No, you won't," she said softly. She didn't touch them, sensing they would flinch from it, but she met their terrified gaze. "You have something to say. That's why you write those loud, angry, wonderful songs. Just go out there and say it. We'll be listening." Skyler stared at her for a long second, then gave a single, jerky nod. A tiny fraction of the tension seemed to leave their shoulders. "Right. Say it loud. Got it." They turned and walked away, their stride a little more purposeful.

Chad gathered the three of them in the narrow corridor just behind the stage entrance, the roar of the audience a physical force now. He was vibrating with an energy so intense it seemed he might spontaneously combust. "This is it, you guys! The final! America is watching! Remember your stories, connect with the camera, and leave it all on the stage! Go make television history!" He clapped each of them on the shoulder and then was gone, his headset already crackling with some new, urgent directive. For a brief moment, the three finalists were alone, suspended in the final seconds of their old lives. Marco turned, his perfect smile looking a little tight at the edges. "Reverend," he said, his voice losing its velvety smoothness for a flicker of pure, human sincerity. "It has been an honor. Now go give 'em hell." He winked, a gesture that was finally stripped of its artifice, and Amelia smiled back. "You too, Marco. Sing with love." She glanced at Skyler, who simply raised their chin in a silent gesture of solidarity. The holy trinity, united for one last moment before the warfare.

A stage manager with a clipboard and a tense expression gave Amelia the "one minute" signal. The plan was for her to perform last. She found a dark corner, away from the scurrying technicians, and leaned against the cool concrete wall. The sound of the crowd, the thumping of the show’s theme music, the frantic energy of it all began to fade into a low hum. She closed her eyes. She thought of the cypress knees, soaked in a century of Gainesville’s joys and sorrows. She thought of Beatrice, likely sitting stiffly on her couch, armed with a notepad to document her critiques. She thought of her father, his scratchy voice telling her she had the voice of an angel. She didn't pray to win. She didn't pray for fame. She simply gave thanks for the lost cause that had been so gloriously found, for the strange and winding path that had led her from a quiet swamp-side church to this impossible precipice. "Okay, Amy-girl," she whispered to herself. "Time to fly." The stage manager pointed directly at her, his mouth forming the silent word: "Go." Amelia took a deep breath, the air tasting of electricity and manufactured fog, and walked out of the darkness, straight into the blinding, benevolent light.

The walk from the wings to the center-stage mark felt both impossibly long and over in an instant. The light was a physical presence, a warm, white weight that erased the shadows and bleached the faces in the front rows into pale, indistinct ovals. The sound was a living thing, a roar of applause and cheers that washed over her, so immense it ceased to be individual noises and became a single, vibrating frequency. She found her spot, a simple ‘X’ marked on the floor in matte black tape, and planted her feet. The peacock-blue dress glittered, a galaxy of sequins under the blaze of a hundred lights, but Amelia felt the solid, reassuring weight of her own body, grounded to the stage. She was not a spectacle. She was a witness.

The first spare, soulful notes of the introduction drifted through the theater, the electric piano and gentle guitar instantly hushing the crowd. The sound was cleaner, richer than it had been in rehearsal, filling the vast space with a feeling of mournful anticipation. Amelia closed her eyes for a single beat, not in prayer, but in communion. She was back in St. Jude’s-in-the-Swamp, standing in a slanted column of afternoon light, the empty pews her most honest audience. She breathed in, and when she breathed out, the first words of the song were carried on the air, not as a performance, but as a testimony. "I was born by the river, in a little tent…" Her voice was low and intimate, a sound that seemed to ignore the thousands of people and millions of television viewers, aimed instead at a single listener, drawing them close.

In the control booth, Jocelyn and Chad stood side-by-side, their faces illuminated by a bank of monitors. Jocelyn, who had tried to script every moment, found herself speechless. This wasn’t the “righteous” or “immovable” narrative she had settled on. This was something else entirely, something raw and unmanageable. It was truth. Chad simply stared at the main monitor showing Amelia’s face, a close-up of pure, unadorned emotion. “Gold,” he whispered, the word stripped of its usual crassness, spoken with a kind of reverence. On the side of the stage, Marco watched, his professional composure melting away into simple admiration. Skyler, who had performed earlier with a furious, cathartic energy that had electrified the room, stood perfectly still, their usual mask of irony gone, their expression one of rapt attention.

Amelia didn’t see any of it. She was inside the song now, living in its verses. She wasn't acting out the struggle Dex had demanded; she was inhabiting it with her voice. When she sang of being pushed around, of being told to not hang around, the note of defiance wasn't a theatrical choice, it was the sound of a spirit refusing to be broken. It was the sound of every small battle she had fought that week, of every parishioner she had championed, of every time she had chosen her own difficult truth over an easier path. The song unfurled from her, a ribbon of sound that climbed higher and higher, the early gentleness giving way to a strength that was as solid and unyielding as the old cypress knees of her church.

Then came the turn. The bridge. The moment where despair begins to pivot toward hope. "Then I go to my brother, and I say, 'Brother, help me please.'" The plea was so vulnerable, so naked, it hushed the theater into an even deeper silence. And then the reply: "'But he winds up knockin' me back down on my knees.'" She didn't fall to her knees as Dex had wanted. She stood taller, her shoulders squaring as if absorbing the blow, her voice ringing with the pain of betrayal. She held the last note of the line, letting the sorrow hang in the air for a heart-stopping moment. And then, she let it go. The final section began, not as a quiet hope, but as a full-throated, gospel-infused declaration. "There've been times that I thought I couldn't last for long, but now I think I'm able to carry on." The power that Debra had coaxed out of her, the sound forged in gospel choirs and her daddy’s blues records, was finally unleashed, glorious and unrestrained.

It culminated in the final, iconic line. She took a breath that seemed to draw in all the energy of the room, and then she sang it. "It's been a long… a long time comin'… but I know…" She held the pause, a moment of perfect, unbearable tension, her gaze lifted not to the cameras, but to the unseen heavens above the lighting rigs. "…A change is gonna come." The final three words were not a shout. They were a promise, a sermon, and a benediction all in one. She held the final note, a sound of pure, gut-punching soul, letting it soar and expand until it filled every corner of the theater, vibrating in the bones of everyone present. She held it until her lungs burned, her eyes shut tight, just as she had in the empty sanctuary. The silence that followed was absolute. It was a cathedral silence, heavy and profound, filled with the ghost of the song. For two full seconds, nobody moved, nobody breathed. Then, the theater erupted. It wasn't just applause; it was a roar, a standing ovation that was less a judgment and more a shared, spontaneous catharsis. Amelia opened her eyes, a giddy, tear-streaked smile on her lips, and bowed. She wasn't Amy the singer or Amelia the Reverend.
